Subsubsection Text: We are a leading global manufacturer of mission critical compressors, controls, components and solutions to the heating, ventilation, air conditioning, and refrigeration (“HVACR”) market. We provide products that help enhance human health and comfort, protect food quality and safety, advance energy efficiency, and create environmentally sustainable infrastructure. Key components in an HVACR ecosystem include the compressor, controls, the condenser and the evaporator. We provide best-in-class compressors, controls, components and solutions for residential, commercial, industrial and transportation applications. We are the largest global manufacturer in our served markets with approximately 40% share in overall global compression, including approximately 70% in the North America residential heating, ventilation and air conditioning (“HVAC”) segment, and strong positions within our non-compression offerings. Our large installed base of more than 150 million HVAC compressor units globally drives profitable aftermarket sales due to replacement dynamics, with approximately 80% of our net sales tied to repair or replacement activity. Ongoing technology leadership is a key driver of our ability to capitalize on the replacement cycle, as each successive generation of compressor provides greater cost savings, energy efficiency and higher levels of environmental sustainability impact. The replacement cycle is primarily driven by repair and replacement of HVACR systems. Our installed base provides a foundation for ongoing earnings resilience as systems age and require repair or replacement. Global regulations around the impact of refrigerants on global warming and the need for energy efficiency amplify replacement dynamics in our business. Globally, government programs and incentives support the adoption of new, more sustainable products creating a strong forward looking growth environment. Secular trends tied to human health and comfort, as well as food quality, safety and sustainability drive additional demand for our compression and solutions offerings. As the heart of an HVAC system, the compressor is the system’s most critical component, yet represents a small percentage of the unit cost to the consumer. For example, approximately three to five percent of the residential HVAC unit cost is associated with the compressor, but the compressor has a mission-critical impact on function and efficiency. Compressors enable the separation of the low-pressure side of an HVAC system, where heat is absorbed into the refrigerant, from the high-pressure side of the system, where heat is discharged from the refrigerant to a cooling medium (typically the ambient outside air). The compressor mechanically reduces the volume of low-side refrigerant, thereby increasing its pressure and enabling heated refrigerant to flow to the high-pressure side of the system, where it is cooled. ----- We offer a variety of compressor technologies to meet customer-specific applications. Compression technology is essential to improving system efficiency. In addition, refrigerant selection is dependent on rigorous testing by compressor manufacturers to evaluate for performance and reliability and approve for use. Globally, the HVACR system manufacturers are dependent upon compressor innovation to meet regulations for efficiency and more environmentally friendly refrigerants. Because compressors are highly engineered to meet our customers’ technical requirements, we work closely with them on engineering, research and development (“ER&D”) efforts to develop technology that meets consumer needs and complies with regulatory changes. These tightly coupled relationships result from our industry leadership and help provide us with good forward-looking visibility to market needs and opportunities to differentiate ourselves.

Subsubsection Title: Business Unit Overview
Subsubsection Text: Our business is organized into two broad categories (HVACR Technologies and Electronics and Controls), with three world areas included within the HVACR Technologies group (HVACR Americas, HVACR AMEA (Asia, Middle-East and Africa) and HVACR Europe). Further, for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024, we generated net sales and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA of $4,722.7 million and $1,361.0 million, respectively. See “Summary Historical Consolidated and Combined Financial Information” for a reconciliation of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA to net earnings, the closest comparable GAAP measure. **NET SALES MIX[(1) ]** (1) As of the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsubsection Title: HVACR Technologies
Subsubsection Text: The businesses within our HVACR Technologies group are leading producers of compression and related controls and solutions for residential, commercial, refrigeration, industrial, and transport markets. Our pioneering leadership of the scroll type of compressor enables foundational leadership across a majority of our served markets. To meet the diverse needs of other compressor applications, we also provide hermetic, semi-hermetic, centrifugal, screw and reciprocating compressors. The depth and breadth of our portfolio is unmatched globally, allowing us to steward market change and innovation across a wide range of market segments and applications. Our global HVACR Technologies group generated 84% of our total net sales and 87% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

We believe compressors lie at the nexus of energy efficiency, helping build environmental sustainability and playing a role in ESG-related trends. Environmental sustainability is inherently embedded in what we do, as we enable our customers to set environmental sustainability goals and consistently meet or exceed ever-increasing sustainability standards. The best compressors—the most energy efficient, the quietest, the most reliable—are also the most environmentally sustainable and the most cost efficient for our original equipment manufacturer (“OEM”) customers and the end users of their products. Consistently improving energy efficiency and sustainability requires continued technological innovation which is made possible by our extensive and proven ER&D capabilities. -----

Subsection Title: HVACR Americas is our largest business unit and operates within an environment where our scroll
Subsubsection Text: technology is extremely well-suited for applications across the served market. This business unit generated 57% of our total net sales and 59% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Our leading positions with the largest North American OEMs serving the residential, commercial and transportation segments is augmented by our leadership with a more fragmented set of refrigeration and industrial customers. Above and beyond the growth that an accelerated energy efficiency and low GWP refrigerant regulatory environment is driving for our core residential, commercial and refrigeration markets, our industrial business is well-positioned for sustainability-driven growth within the renewable natural gas (“RNG”) segment. The industrial business is roughly divided 50/50 between traditional industrial refrigeration applications and RNG applications. The RNG space is growing at a double-digit compound annual growth rate the past few years and growth is expected to accelerate given sustainability trends and the associated policies and incentives to deal with landfill and other off-gassing, largely farm-digestor applications. We are well-positioned with key customers in this space, as well as with their solution providers and engineering contractors. Broad heating, cooling and refrigeration needs across the Americas region coupled with a mature regulatory environment provide a solid foundation for continued growth and innovation opportunities. ----- Our leadership in HVACR AMEA is driven by balanced sales between residential, commercial and refrigeration applications. Our technology leadership in commercial, district and other heating and refrigeration segments in China is complemented by our broad leadership positions in the rest of the region, including high ambient temperature and residential applications in countries such as Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. HVACR AMEA generated 18% of our net sales and 22% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsection Title: HVACR Europe has historically been a strong commercial and refrigeration market and is now the fastest
Subsubsection Title: Electronics and Controls
Subsubsection Text: Our Electronics and Controls business unit is a global leader in cold chain controls, monitoring solutions and climate control products and solutions. We provide building and refrigeration controls and monitoring solutions for food retail and foodservice applications, refrigerated container and perishable cargo monitoring solutions for cargo and marine applications and healthcare environmental safety monitoring solutions. Our business benefits from sustainability, energy management and digitalization tailwinds, including integrated refrigeration solutions across compressors and controls, market penetration opportunities with leading automation capabilities, expanding data services and analytics in cargo monitoring, and healthcare monitoring and grid-connected energy management solutions. We also provide traditional and connected thermostats, energy and building management solutions, gas valves, cooling controls and control electronics. Our business benefits from energy efficiency, connectivity and control tailwinds, including opportunities to support hospitality and multi-dwelling unit customers in achieving energy efficiency goals with smart thermostats and energy management software solutions. Our Electronics and Controls business unit generated 16% of our net sales and 13% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsection Title: HVACR Europe has historically been a strong commercial and refrigeration market and is now the fastest
Subsubsection Title: Product Offerings and Market Segments
Subsubsection Text: Within our two business units, we provide products and services across five key market segments, namely Commercial, Electronics and Control, Industrial, Refrigeration and Residential, throughout the Americas, AMEA and Europe. **NET SALES MIX[(1) ]** (1) As of the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Totals may exceed 100% due to rounding. ----- Across the Copeland brand, as well as the Sensi, Verdant, Vilter and White-Rodgers sub-brands, we provide products that help enhance human health and comfort, protect food quality and safety, advance energy efficiency, and create environmentally sustainable infrastructure. Comprising approximately 81% of our total net sales for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our HVACR market segments, including residential and commercial HVAC compression, refrigeration and related aftermarket, and industrial, play an important role for our business (approximately 36% residential HVAC compression, approximately 20% commercial HVAC compression, approximately 22% refrigeration and related aftermarket, and approximately 4% industrial). In addition, for the three months ended March 31, 2024, approximately 82% of our total net sales were generated from our HVACR compression market segment, consisting of approximately 34% residential HVAC compression (representing a 15% decrease in year over year sales), approximately 20% commercial HVAC compression (representing a 1% increase in year over year sales), approximately 23% refrigeration and related aftermarket (representing a 5% increase in year over year sales), and approximately 5% industrial (representing a 39% increase in year over year sales). The compressor is the most critical device within the HVACR system, and the most energy-intensive HVACR component. Each unit is engineered to meet application, segment, and customer requirements to efficiently separate the evaporator low-pressure side of the system from the condenser high-pressure side. There are six categories of compressor technology. We invented scroll technology and continue to innovate and scale this technology platform. Scroll’s flexibility in modulation, superior efficiency and advantages in performance best positions it to keep up with evolving industry technical requirements and to win share from other technology types. While scroll is the leading technology for a majority of our served HVACR applications, certain applications are better suited to other technologies. We have developed a full suite of technology options, including a new offering in oil-free centrifugal, to meet a wide range of customer technology needs. Our leading portfolio across operating parameters and served applications creates opportunities for us to leverage global ER&D efforts and to apply learnings from one segment or region to other segments or regions thus driving productivity and improving our ability to capture new opportunities in a timely fashion. In addition to our compression solutions, our Electronics and Controls market segment (to be distinguished from our Electronic and Controls business unit) generated approximately 19% of our total net sales for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024 and approximately 18% for the last three months ended March 31, 2024 (representing a 10% decrease in year over year sales). Our portfolio of “control” products includes perishable and environmental monitoring solutions, control systems, thermostats, food safety instruments and software solutions. These products support climate and energy management in residential and commercial buildings, as well as across the cold chain. -----

Subsection Title: HVACR Europe has historically been a strong commercial and refrigeration market and is now the fastest
Subsubsection Title: Customers and Distribution Channels
Subsubsection Text: Our customers include the world’s largest HVAC system OEMs and regional and local HVAC providers, as well as distributors, wholesalers and end users. Through our market and technology leadership and global production capacity, we have achieved significant share with leading OEMs who represent approximately one-third of global sales. Our approximately 800 other customers account for the other two-thirds of global sales. These longtenured OEM relationships provide long-term volume stability, scale and influence. Our highly diversified customer base helps minimize risks associated with customer concentration. We tailor our go-to-market strategy across the value chain to best suit specific segments and end customers. Approximately two-thirds of our products are sold directly to OEMs globally. OEM customers seek advantages in efficiency, applied cost and compressor performance to reduce design complexity and improve performance. We also sell our products directly to secondary buyers such as distributors and contractors. Our strong reputation for product quality and durability, which reduce warranty costs for OEMs and the total long-term cost of ownership for end customers, has pull-through effects on OEMs and the entire value chain. We further collaborate with channel influencers, such as researchers, regulators, technical schools and utility providers, to create connectivity with the entire HVACR ecosystem. In the food retail and food service industries, we work directly with end users as well as the OEMs to provide solutions, which are sold either to the OEM, through intermediaries or directly to the end user. We and our customers invest significant time and resources in designing products to meet required specifications for each application and technology platform. As a result, we are highly integrated with our customers, augmenting our strong market position. OEMs launch new product platforms every seven to ten years, typically in connection with new regulatory standards. These new platforms require significant redesigns that need many years of product development and close alignment between the OEM and its compressor suppliers. This dynamic inherently favors our company due to the long-standing, close working relationships between our engineering teams and our key OEM customers. Between formal launches, platforms are continually modified to reduce cost and improve efficiency and reliability. The redesign process is less significant and favors the original compressor supplier on the OEM platform. In addition to our integration in the development cycle, we have built channels and technical support structures with OEM partners, where they rely on us to provide aftermarket support and continue to service the installed base. Our role as a trusted partner in customer design and manufacturing processes has resulted in low customer turnover. Our technological advantage, deeply integrated partnerships with OEM customers and strong quality performance together make us indispensable to our customers and support our ability to maintain margins despite rising input costs. Long-term volume-based agreements (“LTAs”) include mechanisms to pass through material cost inflation in order to provide stability and resiliency. On average, LTAs are three to four years in length and approximately one-third of our total net sales are covered by LTAs.

Subsection Title: HVACR Europe has historically been a strong commercial and refrigeration market and is now the fastest
Subsubsection Title: Technology Leadership
Subsubsection Text: The ongoing cycle of periodic new platform launches and subsequent updates provides us with line of sight into future customer technology needs, enabling us to tailor our ER&D efforts around anticipated customer demands. In doing so, we help OEMs keep pace with and shape technology innovations in the HVACR industry. We have developed a robust and repeatable ER&D process to enable us to be a consistent innovation pioneer. Key capabilities include: technology discovery and maturation; front-end innovation; world class laboratories and ecosystems; specialized technical expertise; partnerships with universities, national labs and government agencies; regulatory agency and industry leadership; and new product development support. With more than 1,400 engineering and ER&D employees and approximately 500,000 square feet of engineering labs at 12 major ER&D centers worldwide, including three in Asia and five in Europe, we have substantial infrastructure to build on our technology leadership. Our ER&D strategy is further supported by the development of the Helix Innovation Center (the “Helix”), an industry-first space where stakeholders can innovate at a system or ecosystem level around the industry’s biggest, most complex challenges. The Helix includes six simulated real-world, fully functional environments allowing us to test and demonstrate our integrated solutions in ----- ----- total annual sales in the market segments addressable by our current product offerings is approximately $13.4 billion and such market is expected to grow at a compound annual rate of approximately 4% over the next five years. Demand in our markets is supported by attractive macro drivers such as global regulation shifts, industrydriven sustainability goals and regulatory subsidies and incentives. Based on our current market positioning, our global scale and flexibility of our supply chain, and our manufacturing and ER&D capabilities, we are wellpositioned to capitalize on these trends. - **Regulatory Changes: Regulatory changes have driven change and innovation in our industry for decades. However, the frequency and impact of those changes has increased in recent years. These changes include updates to seasonal energy efficiency ratio (“SEER”) requirements (and other global efficiency standards) and new standards on refrigerants that drive more frequent compressor and system innovations. The complexity resulting from these changes favors our global breadth and the depth of our engineering, technology and operations. In the United States, new efficiency regulations went into effect January 1, 2023. In 2025, new refrigerant regulations will again drive new compressors and systems into the market. Additional new regulations in the next seven to ten years are anticipated. Engineering and development efforts typically begin years in advance of the applicable regulation effective date. Our OEM customers depend on us to help them meet these requirements in a timely fashion while simultaneously helping them innovate and differentiate to meet their sustainability goals. Europe’s sustainability goals and their desire for energy sovereignty is driving goals and incentives targeting the installation of 30 million new heat pumps by 2030. - **Heat Pump Conversion: The growth of heat pumps is expected to bring new customers into the HVAC market, as households convert a furnace-only or gas-only system to a heat pump. According to a major consulting practice, consumers enjoy on average approximately $4,000 in lifetime savings from heat pumps, supported by government subsidy programs and incentives available from utility providers. Conversion to heat pumps is expected to be particularly strong in Europe, where high natural gas prices are incentivizing a transition to less energy-intensive heat pumps. The European Union (“EU”) is in the process of revising its Energy Performance Building Directive (“EPBD”) to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 55% by 2030, a legal obligation under the European climate law, and make the EU climate-neutral by 2050. While the revision is still under negotiation, the EPBD is expected to require member states to ensure that all new buildings after 2027 are zero-emission, and set deadlines after which the use of fossil fuel heating systems in new buildings, or in major building renovations or renovations of the heating systems, will not be permitted. Existing regulations across nine European countries have already implemented, or will implement by 2026, fossil fuel boiler bans in residential buildings. With the upcoming revision of the EPBD, we expect that all other EU member states will implement similar restrictions and the scope will ultimately comprise all existing buildings. Some countries also already provide, or are expected to provide, monetary incentives to accelerate the transition to clean heating, including heat pumps. With strong channel benefits and an existing customer base, the major legacy boilermakers are playing a critical role in the heat pump transition. Our HVAC compression expertise positions us as an important partner as legacy boilermakers help to drive heat pump adoption. Our partnership and existing share with legacy boilermakers and HVAC OEMs positions us well to enable this transition. We are currently a leader in compression for the heat pump segment in Europe. - **COVID-19 / Hybrid Working: More waking hours spent at home are expected to maintain HVAC usage above pre-COVID-19 levels, shortening system useful life. According to a major consulting practice, these new working arrangements are expected to keep replacement rates elevated as approximately 45% of employees are predicted to be in hybrid working models in the future versus approximately 10% pre-COVID-19. HVACR industry executives also expect replacement rates to remain elevated. Run times in 2020 were quoted as being 30% higher than 2019 levels (after adjusting for weather), which should correlate to higher rates of replacement over time. - **Environmental and Population Shifts: With environmental change resulting in more extreme temperatures across the United States, and a population mix increasingly shifting to warmer southern ----- states, HVAC usage has increased and is expected to continue to increase, resulting in shorter useful lives for HVAC equipment and higher replacement rates.

Subsection Title: HVACR Europe has historically been a strong commercial and refrigeration market and is now the fastest
Subsubsection Text: growing business unit as fossil-fueled boiler systems are being replaced by heat pump and dual fuel solutions, applications where we are a leading compressor and solutions provider. HVACR Europe generated 9% of our net sales and 6% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsubsection Title: Established global leader with clear #1 market position
Subsubsection Text: We are the #1 manufacturer of HVACR compression products in the segments and regions where we compete, driven by technology leadership, strong brand recognition, global facilities footprint and long-term customer relationships. We are the clear leader in terms of global scale and presence, as well as breadth and quality of our product portfolio, and we compete against different peers in each segment and region where we operate. Our size and scale enable operational synergies driven by our ability to leverage technology, ER&D and manufacturing excellence across regions.

Subsubsection Title: Unrivaled breadth and depth of product portfolio and capabilities executed through a global ER&D supply network, and well-positioned for innovation
Subsubsection Text: Our global manufacturing capabilities, paired with our leading portfolio of SKUs and patents, enable us to provide what our customers need, where they need it, and when they need it. No competitor can match our global reach across markets and segments. Our leading technology position is supported by more than 3,000 patents and pending applications. Extensive ER&D capabilities in the United States and Asia, along with a growing ER&D functionality in Europe, enable us to offer truly global ER&D capabilities to meet the needs of each individual customer and application. These capabilities, combined with our deeply integrated relationships with leading OEMs and decades of experience have made us an industry leader in technological advancement. We work collaboratively with regulators to understand future efficiency capability standards and we are developing the solutions to meet those standards with the world’s leading HVACR manufacturers. Leveraging these partnerships and our global ER&D infrastructure, we are able to take a leadership position in shaping each wave of regulatory transition. Our deep appreciation of the end user helps us tailor our technology to each customer’s needs, bringing our global expertise to provide local solutions. This continued technological leadership has helped make us the most trusted name in compressor solutions. Given our manufacturing presence and ER&D capabilities, we are wellpositioned for the industry’s transition to heat pumps. Planned and anticipated regulatory changes governing efficiency and refrigerants are expected to provide stable, ongoing tailwinds to both price and volume. New regulations from the U.S. Department of Energy went into effect in 2023, with energy efficiency requirements varied by region, and OEM partners are relying on us to design products that comply with the new regulations. The anticipated transition to low-GWP refrigerants in 2025 will require considerable engineering, given that compliant refrigerants exhibit different characteristics from existing refrigerants, such as operating pressures and flammability.

Subsubsection Title: Mission critical partner to a diversified global customer base characterized by long-term relationships
Subsubsection Text: As the heart of an HVAC system, the compressor is the system’s most critical component, yet represents a small percentage of the unit cost to the consumer. For example, approximately three to five percent of the residential HVAC unit cost is associated with the compressor, but the product has a mission-critical impact on function and efficiency. Compression innovation can create performance, reliability and cost advantages to system design, therefore enabling value-based selling. Customers will pay a premium for compressors that achieve superior levels of efficiency, enabling them to reduce other costs within the system design and resulting in an overall lower total applied system cost. We and our customers invest significant time and resources in designing products to meet specifications required by each application and technology platform. As a result, we are highly integrated with our customers, augmenting our industry leadership and helping provide us with good forward-looking visibility to market needs and ----- opportunities to differentiate. LTAs further support revenue visibility and customer retention. Outside of the United States, where the customer base is more diversified and fragmented, LTAs are utilized less frequently.

Subsubsection Title: Highly engineered offering promotes customer retention through customer process integration
Subsubsection Text: In addition to the critical nature of compressors within HVAC systems, we also serve as a critical engineering, development, and manufacturing partner to our customers. We provide crucial services to our customers at every stage of the product lifecycle by: - Helping customers develop specifications to meet new regulatory requirements - Innovating compressor technology to meet the requirements - Manufacturing units at scale and on time to support new platform launches - Developing updates to existing platforms in partnership with customers - Providing aftermarket products and services to help end-users realize the full useful lives of their HVACR systems Deep interconnectivity with our customers’ design and manufacturing processes helps us to provide bestin-class service and support to our customers. This deep integration incentivizes our customers to maintain their relationships with us. Customer turnover is less than one percent historically. Our technical expertise and operational support make us a trusted partner.

Subsubsection Title: Resilient business model supported by established installed base and high replacement volumes
Subsubsection Text: Replacement as a percent of sales has increased to more than 85% over the last 50 years in the North America residential HVAC industry, with a current installed base of approximately 100 million units. Replacement sales are more resilient and are associated with durable spend, often outperforming gross domestic product growth rates during economic cycles. Both HVACR systems broadly and compressors specifically suffer from wear. Compressors may be replaced to extend the life of an HVACR system. Full system replacement occurs when HVACR units are beyond repair or when an end-user determines that the payback in higher efficiency, lower emissions and better reliability is sufficient to warrant the cost of replacement. Repair or replacement of a unit is non-discretionary because HVACR systems provide essential heating, cooling and refrigeration. Our resilient recovery during the 2007-2008 Global Financial Crisis speaks to the largely non-discretionary nature of HVAC repair and replacement. Despite an approximately 15% revenue contraction in 2009, our revenues rebounded quickly in 2010 with more than 19% growth before returning to normalized long-term growth rates. Over the same period, we delivered improvements in gross margin and EBITDA margin as we moved quickly to manage costs. Our cost structure is largely variable, enabling us to preserve margin during downturns such as the 2007-2008 Global Financial Crisis, the U.S. manufacturing downturn, and the COVID-19 pandemic. Secular industry tailwinds, including upcoming regulatory changes, heat pump conversion, shifts in population and the impact of hybrid working, are expected to drive an increase in HVAC usage. This increase in usage can create more wear on HVAC systems and shorten systems’ useful lives, resulting in increased repair and replacement rates and driving further demand for replacement products supporting our long-term resilient growth.

Subsubsection Title: Proven leadership team with an unmatched breadth of experience
Subsubsection Text: Our business is led by a highly qualified and experienced management team. Our management consistently delivered value to stakeholders while operating as a standalone segment of Emerson. In partnership with Blackstone, the Copeland team continues to drive innovation and execute on operational excellence in order to capitalize on strong industry tailwinds. -----

Subsubsection Title: Strong financial profile with best-in-class profitability and free cash flow generation, poised for margin expansion through identified efficiency opportunities
Subsubsection Text: We have delivered robust and consistent through-the-cycle cash flow performance and top-line growth, supported by secular industry tailwinds, technology leadership, embedded relationships with customers, and the mission-critical nature of our product offerings.

Subsubsection Title: Transaction Agreement
Subsubsection Text: On October 30, 2022, the Issuer entered into the Transaction Agreement with Emerson, BCP Emerald and JV NewCo. The Acquisition was consummated on May 31, 2023, the result of which is (i) JV NewCo holds Climate Technologies Business, (ii) BCP Emerald acquired approximately 60% of the issued and outstanding common equity interests of JV NewCo and 100% of the convertible preferred equity interests of JV NewCo, with an initial liquidation preference of $2.0 billion (the “Convertible PIK Preferred Equity”) and (iii) Emerson retained the remaining 40% of the issued and outstanding common equity interests of JV NewCo. Emerson received cash proceeds of approximately $9.5 billion and two senior unsecured notes issued by EMRLD Seller Notes Issuer L.P., a Delaware limited partnership and a wholly owned subsidiary of JV NewCo (the “Seller Notes Issuer”) and the direct parent entity of Holdings, in an aggregate principal amount of $2.25 billion (the “Seller Notes”).

Subsubsection Title: Financing Transactions
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the closing of the Acquisition, JV NewCo, the Seller Notes Issuer, the Investor Group, or the Issuer, as the case may be, entered into the following financing transactions (the “Initial Financing Transactions”): - the borrowing by the Issuer of $2,275.0 million under the term loan B facility (the “Original Term Loan B Facility”) and $450.0 million under the term loan A facility (the “Term Loan A Facility”) and the Issuer obtaining $700.0 million in commitments under the Revolving Credit Facility (the “Revolving Credit Facility”); - the issuance by the Seller Notes Issuer of $2,250 million aggregate principal amount of two senior unsecured notes (the “Seller Notes”) to EMR Holdings, Inc., an affiliate of Emerson (“EMR ----- Holdings”), which are structurally subordinated to the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Existing Notes and will be structurally subordinated to the notes offered hereby; - the issuance by JV NewCo of $2,000 million initial liquidation preference of the Convertible PIK Preferred Equity to the Investor Group; - the issuance by the Issuers of $2,275 million aggregate principal amount of dollar notes and €455 million aggregate principal amount of euro notes; and - the investment of $2,521 million in the common equity of JV NewCo by the Investor Group.

Subsubsection Title: Term Loan B Facility Refinancing and New Notes Issuance
Subsubsection Text: On February 6, 2024, the Company entered into the following refinancing transactions (the “Refinancing Transactions” and, together with the Initial Financing Transactions, the “Financing Transactions”): - the refinancing of the Original Term Loan B Facility and the incurrence of new senior secured term “B” loans (the “Refinanced Term Loan B Facility”) in an aggregate principal amount of $1,519.3 million; and - the issuance by the Issuers of $500.0 million aggregate principal amount of additional dollar notes and €230 million aggregate principal amount of additional euro notes.

Subsubsection Title: Seller Notes Repurchase
Subsubsection Text: On June 6, 2024, JV NewCo entered into a Note Purchase Agreement (the “Note Purchase Agreement”) with Seller Notes Issuer, Emerson and EMR Holdings. Upon the terms and subject to the conditions set forth in the Note Purchase Agreement, at the closing of the transactions contemplated by the Note Purchase Agreement (the “Seller Notes Repurchase”), (i) the Seller Notes Issuer will repurchase the Seller Notes issued by the Seller Notes Issuer to EMR Holdings on May 31, 2023 and (ii) Emerson will receive cash proceeds of $1.9 billion. Each party’s obligation to consummate the Seller Notes Repurchase is subject to the satisfaction or waiver of various customary closing conditions set forth in the Note Purchase Agreement, including (i) the absence of any law or order that prohibits the consummation of the Seller Notes Repurchase, (ii) obtaining certain regulatory approvals and (iii) other customary closing conditions and the accuracy of each party’s representations and warranties and each party’s compliance with its covenants and agreements contained in the Note Purchase Agreement (subject, in the case of this clause (iii), to certain materiality qualifiers). The parties to the Note Purchase Agreement have each made customary representations, warranties and covenants in the Note Purchase Agreement. The Note Purchase Agreement contains certain other termination rights for the parties thereto, including the right of each party to terminate the agreement if the Seller Notes Repurchase has not been consummated by December 31, 2024 (the “Outside Date”). The Seller Notes Issuer expects to finance the Seller Notes Repurchase with the net proceeds of this offering, borrowings under the New Term Loan B Facility and cash on hand.

Subsubsection Title: Unit Purchase Transaction
Subsubsection Text: On June 6, 2024, BCP Emerald entered into a Unit Purchase Agreement (the “Unit Purchase Agreement” and, together with the Note Purchase Agreement, the “Purchase Agreements”) with JV NewCo, Emerald JV ----- Holdings G.P. LLC, a Delaware limited liability company and the general partner of JV NewCo and certain whollyowned subsidiaries of Emerson (the “Unit Sellers”). Upon the terms and subject to the conditions set forth in the Unit Purchase Agreement, at the closing of the transactions contemplated by the Unit Purchase Agreement (the “Unit Purchase Transaction”), (i) BCP Emerald will acquire approximately 40% common equity interest of JV NewCo held by Emerson through the Unit Sellers, reducing Emerson’s equity interest in JV NewCo to zero and (ii) Emerson will receive cash proceeds of $1.5 billion. BCP Emerald expects to finance the Unit Purchase Transaction with the issuance of new equity from the Sponsors and certain co-investors. The closings of the Unit Purchase Transaction and the Seller Notes Repurchase are not required to occur simultaneously. Additionally, this offering is not conditioned upon the closing of the transactions contemplated by the Purchase Agreements.

If the Seller Notes Repurchase is not consummated simultaneously with this offering, concurrently with the closing of this offering, the Issuers will enter into an escrow agreement relating to the notes (the “Escrow Agreement”) with U.S. Bank Trust Company, National Association, as trustee for the notes and U.S. Bank National Association and/or another nationally recognized financial institution chosen by the Issuer in its reasonable discretion (in such capacity, the “Escrow Agent”), pursuant to which the Issuer will deposit (or cause to be deposited) an amount equal to the gross proceeds of the notes offered hereby into an escrow account for the notes until the conditions to release of the property in the escrow account (the “Escrow Release Conditions”) are satisfied. If, among other things, the Seller Notes Repurchase is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date, the Issuer will redeem, on the Special Mandatory Redemption Date (as defined below) in accordance with the terms of the indenture that will govern the notes, all of the notes at the Special Mandatory Redemption Price (the “Special Mandatory Redemption”).

The table below sets forth the estimated sources and uses of funds in connection with the Seller Notes Repurchase (and after the gross proceeds from this offering are released from escrow, if applicable), assuming it occurred on March 31, 2024, and based on estimated amounts outstanding on that date. Actual amounts will vary from the estimated amounts shown below depending on several factors, including, among others, changes made to the sources of the contemplated financings and differences from our estimated fees and expenses. If the Seller Notes Repurchase is not consummated simultaneously with the consummation of this offering, the gross proceeds of this offering will be funded into escrow and, upon satisfaction of the Escrow Release Conditions, the gross proceeds from this offering, together with borrowings under the New Term Loan B Facility and cash on hand, will be used to fund the Seller Notes Repurchase as set forth below or, if applicable, such gross proceeds will be used to fund the Special Mandatory Redemption as described herein. See “—Escrow.” In addition, at the closing of the Unit Purchase Transaction (i) BCP Emerald will acquire approximately 40% common equity interest of JV NewCo held by Emerson through the Unit Sellers, reducing Emerson’s equity interest in JV NewCo to zero and (ii) Emerson will receive cash proceeds of $1.5 billion. ----- You should read the following together with the information included under the headings “The Transactions— Seller Notes Repurchase” and “Capitalization” included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

(“Seller Not|r Notes Issuer P. es Issuer”)| |---|---| |EMRLD Gu (“Holdi|arantor LP ngs”)(3)| |---|---| |EMRLD B (“Issu|orrower LP er”)(2)| |---|---| ----- ADIA is a public institution established by the Government of the Emirate of Abu Dhabi in 1976 as an independent investment institution. ADIA manages a global investment portfolio that is diversified across more than two dozen asset classes and sub categories. With a long tradition of prudent investing, ADIA’s decisions are based solely on its economic objectives of delivering sustained, long-term financial returns. GIC is a leading global investment firm established in 1981 to manage Singapore’s foreign reserves. A disciplined long-term value investor, GIC is uniquely positioned for investments across a wide range of asset classes, including equities, fixed income, private equity, real estate and infrastructure. In private equity, GIC invests through funds as well as directly in companies, partnering with its fund managers and management teams to help world class businesses achieve their objectives. GIC has investments in over 40 countries and has been investing in emerging markets for more than two decades. Headquartered in Singapore, GIC employs over 2,100 people across 11 offices in key financial cities worldwide.

The Issuer is a limited partnership formed under the laws of Delaware on December 12, 2022. The CoIssuer is a corporation incorporated under the laws of Delaware on April 11, 2023. Our principal executive office is located at 8100 W. Florissant Avenue, St. Louis, MO 63136, and our telephone number is (314) 553-5555. The Company’s website is www.copeland.com. Information on, or accessible through, this website is not part of this offering memorandum, nor is such content incorporated by reference herein. You should rely only on the information contained in this offering memorandum when making a decision as to whether to invest in the notes offered hereby. -----

Subsubsection Text: Emerald Co-Issuer Inc., a Delaware corporation and wholly-owned subsidiary of EMRLD Borrower LP, the co-issuer of the notes.

Subsection Title: Securities Offered ......................... $950,000,000 of      % Senior Secured Notes due 2031. Maturity Date ................................ The notes will mature on     , 2031. Interest ........................................... Interest on the notes will accrue at a rate of      % per annum. Interest on the
Subsubsection Text: notes will be payable semi-annually in cash in arrears on      and      of each year, beginning     , 2025. Interest on the notes will accrue from, and including,     , 2024.

Subsection Title: Escrow of Gross Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption .............................. If the Seller Notes Repurchase is not consummated simultaneous with this
Subsubsection Text: offering, concurrently with the closing of the offering of the notes, the Issuers will enter into the Escrow Agreement with the trustee and the Escrow Agent pursuant to which the Issuer will deposit (or cause to be deposited) the gross proceeds of the notes offered hereby into an escrow account for the notes. In the event that the Seller Notes Repurchase is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date or if the Issuer notifies the Escrow Agent that (i) in its reasonable judgment, the Seller Notes Repurchase will not be consummated on or prior to the Outside Date or (ii) the Note Purchase Agreement has been terminated, the Issuers will be required to redeem all of the notes in accordance with the terms of the indenture that will govern the notes at a redemption price (the “Special Mandatory Redemption Price”) equal to 100% of the initial issue price of the notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding, the date of such redemption (the “Special Mandatory Redemption Date”). See “Description of Notes—Escrow of Gross Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.”

Subsection Title: Guarantees .................................... The notes will be fully and unconditionally guaranteed, jointly and severally,
Subsubsection Text: by Holdings and each of the Issuer’s wholly-owned domestic restricted subsidiaries that guarantees our Senior Secured Credit Facilities (other than the Co-Issuer). In the future, each wholly-owned domestic restricted subsidiary of the Issuer that guarantees indebtedness of the Issuers or any guarantor will guarantee the notes, subject to certain exceptions. As of the issue date of the notes, none of our foreign subsidiaries will guarantee the notes, and no such subsidiaries (existing or formed in the future) are expected to guarantee the notes in the future. The guarantees are subject to release under specified circumstances. See “Description of Notes—Guarantees.” -----

Subsection Title: Security .......................................... The notes and the guarantees will be secured by the Collateral (as defined in
Subsubsection Text: the “Description of the Notes”). The notes and the guarantees will be secured on an equal priority basis with our Term Loan Facilities by the assets that secure our Term Loan Facilities, which will consist of a senior-priority lien on the Fixed Asset Priority Collateral (as defined in the “Description of the Notes”), and will consist of a junior-priority lien on the ABL Priority Collateral (as defined in the “Description of the Notes”), in each case, subject to certain limitations and exceptions and permitted liens. The lien securing the notes on the Fixed Asset Priority Collateral will be senior to the lien on such Collateral securing our Revolving Credit Facility, and the lien securing the notes on the ABL Priority Collateral will be junior to the lien on such Collateral securing our Revolving Credit Facility. See “Description of Notes—Security for the Notes.”

Subsection Title: Intercreditor Agreements ............ In connection with the issuance of the notes, the Notes Collateral Agent (as
Subsubsection Text: defined herein), the Issuers and certain other parties thereto will enter into a joinder to the existing equal priority intercreditor agreement, dated as of May 31, 2023 (the “Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement”) among the notes collateral agent for our Existing Notes (the “Existing Notes Collateral Agent”), the collateral agent in respect of the Term Loan B Facility and Term Loan A Facility (the “Bank Collateral Agent”), which sets forth the relative rights of, and relationship among, the Notes Collateral Agent, the holders of the notes, the Existing Notes Collateral agent, the holders of the Existing Notes, the Bank Collateral Agent and the lenders under each of our Term Loan Facilities and the applicable representative of the holders under any other equal priority lien indebtedness in respect of the exercise of rights and remedies against the Issuers and the guarantors. In addition, the Notes Collateral Agent, the Issuers and certain other parties thereto will enter into a joinder to the ABL Intercreditor Agreement, dated as of May 31, 2023 (the “ABL Intercreditor Agreement” and together, with the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement, the “Intercreditor Agreements”) among the Existing Notes Collateral Agent, the Bank Collateral Agent and the collateral agent under our Revolving Credit Facility (the “ABL Collateral Agent”), which sets forth the relative priorities of the liens on the Collateral securing the Existing Notes, the notes offered hereby and our Term Loan Facilities and other equal priority lien indebtedness, on the one hand, and our Revolving Credit Facility (or any replacement facilities), on the other hand, and the relative rights of such parties to enforce such liens. See “Description of Notes—Security for the Notes—Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement” and “Description of Notes— Security for the Notes—ABL/Fixed Asset Intercreditor Agreement.”

Subsection Title: Ranking ......................................... The notes will be the Issuers’ and the guarantees will be the guarantors’ senior
Subsubsection Text: secured obligations and will: - rank equally in right of payment with all of the Issuers’ and each guarantor’s existing and future senior indebtedness; - rank senior in right of payment to all of the Issuers’ and each guarantor’s existing and future subordinated indebtedness and other obligations that expressly provide for their subordination to the notes and the guarantees; ----- - be effectively senior to all of the Issuers’ and each guarantor’s existing and future unsecured indebtedness to the extent of the value of the Collateral securing the notes; - rank equally in priority as to the Collateral with respect to borrowings and guarantees under our Term Loan Facilities, our Existing Notes and any other equal priority indebtedness, to the extent of the value of the Collateral; - be effectively subordinated to any of the Issuers’ and the guarantors’ indebtedness that is secured by a senior-priority lien on the ABL Priority Collateral, including the Revolving Credit Facility, to the extent of the value of the ABL Priority Collateral; - be effectively subordinated to any of the Issuers’ and the guarantors’ indebtedness that is secured by assets that do not constitute Collateral to the extent of the value of such assets securing such indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to all existing and future indebtedness, claims of holders of preferred stock and other liabilities of any subsidiary of the Issuers or a guarantor that is not a guarantor or a coissuer of the notes. As of March 31, 2024, after giving effect to this offering, the New Term Loan B Facility and the use of proceeds therefrom, the Issuers and the guarantors would have had approximately $7,388.7 million in total indebtedness outstanding (excluding approximately $9.1 million of issued and undrawn letters of credit) none of which would have been subordinated and all of which would have been senior secured indebtedness, consisting of $950.0 million under the New Term Loan B Facility, $1,965.5 million of borrowings under the Existing Term Loan Facilities, $3,523.2 million (equivalent) of the Existing Notes and $950.0 million of the notes. In addition, as of March 31, 2024, we had approximately $399.5 million of availability to incur additional secured indebtedness under the Revolving Credit Facility, subject to borrowing base capacity (after giving effect to approximately $9.1 million of letters of credit outstanding thereunder). As of and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our non-guarantor subsidiaries represented approximately 40% of our net sales, 57% of our EBITDA, 45% of our total assets and 21% of our total liabilities.

Subsection Title: Optional Redemption ................... Prior to     , 2027, the Issuers may, at their option, at any time and from
Subsubsection Text: time to time, redeem the notes, in whole or in part, at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the notes to be redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date plus the “makewhole premium” described under “Description of Notes—Optional Redemption.” From and after     , 2027, the Issuers may, at their option, at any time and from time to time, redeem the notes, in whole or in part, at the applicable redemption prices set forth in this offering memorandum, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. ----- In addition, prior to     , 2027, the Issuers may, at their option, at any time and from time to time, redeem up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the notes with an amount not to exceed the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price of      % of the principal amount of the notes to be redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. In addition, prior to     , 2027, the Issuers may, at their option, at any time and from time to time, redeem up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the notes during each calendar year following the issuance of the notes at a redemption price of 103% of the principal amount of the notes to be redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. See “Description of Notes—Optional Redemption.”

Subsection Title: Change of Control Offer .............. Upon the occurrence of specific kinds of Change of Control Triggering Events
Subsubsection Text: (as hereinafter defined in “Description of Notes”), if we do not redeem the notes, you will have the right, as holders of the notes, to require the Issuers to purchase some or all of your notes at 101% of their principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the purchase date. See “Description of Notes—Repurchase at the Option of Holders—Change of Control Triggering Event.”

Subsection Title: Certain Covenants ........................ The notes will be issued under an indenture that will contain covenants that
Subsubsection Text: will, among other things, limit the ability of the Issuer and the ability of its restricted subsidiaries to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness or issue disqualified stock or certain preferred stock; - pay dividends and make other distributions or repurchase stock; - make certain investments; - create or incur certain liens; - transfer or sell certain assets; - enter into restrictions affecting the ability of certain restricted subsidiaries to make distributions, loans or advances or transfer assets to the Issuers or the guarantors; - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; - designate restricted subsidiaries as unrestricted subsidiaries; and - merge, consolidate or transfer or sell all or substantially all of the Issuers’ or the guarantors’ assets. These covenants are subject to a number of important limitations and exceptions. Most of these covenants will not apply to the Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries during any period in which the notes are rated investment grade by either Moody’s Investors Service, Inc. (“Moody’s”) or S&P Global Ratings (“S&P”). See “Description of Notes—Certain Covenants.” ----- Transfer Restrictions; No** The notes and the guarantees have not been and will not be registered under the

Subsection Title: Registration Rights .................. Securities Act or any state securities laws. The notes are subject to restrictions
Subsubsection Text: on transfer and resale and may not be offered or sold except under an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the Securities Act and applicable state securities laws. We will not be required to complete a registered exchange offer or file a shelf registration statement for resale of the notes. For more details, see “Transfer Restrictions.”

Subsection Title: No Public Market; Listing ........... The notes will constitute a new class of securities with no established trading
Subsubsection Text: market. We cannot assure you that an active trading market for the notes will develop and continue after this offering. Certain of the initial purchasers have advised us that they currently intend to make a market in the notes. However, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue any market-making activities with respect to the notes at any time without notice. We do not intend to apply for listing of the notes on any securities exchange or on any automated quotation system. Accordingly, we cannot assure you as to the liquidity of, or the trading market for, the notes.

Subsection Title: Trustee, Notes Collateral Agent, Registrar, Paying Agent and Transfer Agent ......................... U.S. Bank Trust Company, National Association Use of Proceeds ............................. If the Seller Notes Repurchase is consummated simultaneously with the
Subsubsection Text: consummation of this offering, we intend to use the proceeds of this offering and borrowings under the New Term Loan B Facility, together with cash on hand, to repurchase certain Seller Notes issued by the Seller Notes Issuer to Emerson and/or for general corporate purposes and to pay fees, costs and expenses related to this offering. If the Seller Notes Repurchase is not consummated simultaneously with the consummation of this offering, the gross proceeds of this offering will be funded into escrow and, upon satisfaction of the Escrow Release Conditions, the gross proceeds from this offering, together with borrowings under the New Term Loan B Facility and cash on hand, will be used to fund the Seller Notes Repurchase or, if applicable, such gross proceeds will be used to fund the Special Mandatory Redemption as described herein. See “—The Transactions” and “Use of Proceeds”.

Subsubsection Text: the purchase, ownership and disposition of the notes, see “Certain United States Federal Income Tax Considerations.”

Subsubsection Text: multiples of $1,000 in excess thereof.

Subsubsection Text: by the laws of the State of New York.

Subsubsection Text: consider all the information included in this offering memorandum before investing in the notes. In particular, you should evaluate the specific risks described in the section entitled “Risk Factors” in this offering memorandum for a discussion of certain risks relating to an investment in the notes. -----

Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL CONSOLIDATED AND COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The following table sets forth summary historical and unaudited condensed, consolidated and combined financial information of the Company for the periods and dates indicated. On May 31, 2023, private equity funds managed by Blackstone Inc. acquired a majority interest in Emerald JV Holdings L.P., a Delaware limited partnership, and its consolidated subsidiaries pursuant to the Transaction Agreement. As a result of the Transactions, a new basis of accounting was created on May 31, 2023. Periods prior to May 31, 2023 reflect the financial statements of Climate Technologies prior to the Acquisition (referred to herein as the “Predecessor” period). Periods subsequent to May 31, 2023, reflect the financial statements of the Company after the Acquisition (referred to herein as the “Successor” period). The Company’s assets and liabilities were adjusted to fair value on the closing date of the Acquisition. Due to the change in the basis of accounting, the consolidated and combined financial statements for the Predecessor and the consolidated financial statements for the Successor are not comparable. The summary historical consolidated and combined balance sheet data as of September 30, 2022 (Predecessor) and the summary historical consolidated balance sheet data as of September 30, 2023 (Successor), the consolidated statement of operations data for the four months ended September 30, 2023 (Successor) and the consolidated and combined statements of operations data for the eight months ended May 31, 2023 (Predecessor) and for the years ended September 30, 2022 and 2021 (Predecessor), the consolidated statement of cash flows data for the four months ended September 30, 2023 (Successor) and the consolidated and combined cash flows data for the eight months ended May 31, 2023 (Predecessor) and for the years ended September 30, 2022 and 2021 (Predecessor) have been derived from the Company’s audited consolidated and combined financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. The summary historical unaudited condensed and consolidated balance sheet data as of March 31, 2024 (Successor) and the unaudited condensed and consolidated statements of operations data for the three months ended March 31, 2024 (Successor), the three months ended March 31, 2023 (Predecessor), the six months ended March 31, 2024 (Successor) and the six months ended March 31, 2023 (Predecessor) and the combined twelve months ended September 30, 2023 and the unaudited condensed and consolidated statements of cash flows data for the six months ended March 31, 2024 (Successor) and the six months ended March 31, 2023 (Predecessor) have been derived from the Company’s unaudited condensed and consolidated financial statements (Successor) and the unaudited condensed, consolidated and combined financial statements (Predecessor) included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. The summary unaudited condensed and consolidated statements of operations data for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 have been derived by taking the consolidated statement of operations data for the four months ended September 30, 2023 (Successor) and the consolidated and combined statements of operations data for the eight months ended May 31, 2023 (Predecessor), adding the unaudited condensed and consolidated statements of operations data for the six months ended March 31, 2024 and subtracting the unaudited condensed and consolidated statements of operations data for the six months ended March 31, 2023. The unaudited condensed and consolidated financial statements (Successor) and the unaudited condensed, consolidated and combined financial statements (Predecessor) have been prepared on the same basis as the audited consolidated and combined financial statements and, in the opinion of management, include all adjustments, consisting of normal recurring adjustments, necessary for a fair statement of the results for those periods. Results for the three and six months ended March 31, 2024 (Successor) and for the three and six months ended March 31, 2023 (Predecessor) are not necessarily indicative of the results that may be expected for the full fiscal year or any future reporting period. The historical results presented below are not necessarily indicative of the results that may be expected for any future period. The following historical and unaudited condensed, consolidated and combined financial information is only a summary and should be read in conjunction with “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and our historical consolidated and combined financial statements and the notes thereto included elsewhere in this offering memorandum, as well as the information included under the headings “Special Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements,” “—The Transactions,” “Risk Factors” and “Capitalization.” -----

Subsubsection Title: Our business is subject to competitive pressures that could affect prices or demand for our products. In particular, the HVACR market may experience periods of structural imbalance between supply and demand that result in periods of pricing volatility, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: We operate in markets that are highly competitive and potentially volatile, and we compete on the basis of product performance, quality, service and/or price across the industries and markets served. Other factors that affect competition in the HVACR market include the development and application of new technologies, an increasing emphasis on the development of more efficient products and new product introductions. Our operations are significantly dependent on the current and future business environment (including capital and consumer spending) and on public funding. A significant element of our competitive strategy is to deliver solutions to our customers by manufacturing high-quality products at the best relevant global cost. Various companies compete with us in one or more product lines and the number of competitors varies by product line. Some of our competitors may have greater financial resources than we have, allowing them to invest in more extensive research and development and/or marketing activity and making them better able to withstand adverse market conditions, and we also compete with many smaller companies. There has been consolidation and new entrants (including non-traditional competitors) within our industry and there may be future consolidation and new entrants which could result in increased competition and significantly alter the dynamics of the competitive landscape in which we operate. Also, the establishment of manufacturing operations in low-cost countries could provide cost advantages to existing and emerging competitors. There is always the risk of disruptive technologies coming from companies that are not traditionally manufacturers or service providers of our products. Competitive pressures could adversely affect prices or customer demand for our products, impacting our sales or profit margins, and/or resulting in a loss of market share. We also believe that the HVACR market may, from time to time, experience periods of structural imbalance between supply and demand, and that any such excess capacity will put pressure on pricing. Such supply and demand may also be influenced by trade measures and policies, government regulations, public funding, raw material availability, and supply chain disruptions. There may be additional pressure on global demand and average selling prices in the future resulting from fluctuating demand in certain major markets. If our competitors reduce pricing to levels near or below their manufacturing costs, or are able to operate at minimal or negative operating margins for sustained periods of time, or if global HVACR demand decreases relative to installed production capacity, our business, financial condition, and results of operations could be adversely affected.

Subsubsection Title: Our operating results depend in part on continued successful research, development and marketing of new and/or improved products and services, and there can be no assurance that we will continue to successfully introduce new products and services.
Subsubsection Text: The success of new and improved products and services depends on their initial and continued acceptance by our customers. Our business is affected by varying degrees of technological change and corresponding shifts in customer demand, which result in unpredictable product transitions, shortened life cycles and increased importance of being first to market with new products and services. The development and commercialization of new products ----- and the modification of existing products and services to meet customer demands require a significant investment of resources and an anticipation of the impact of new technologies and the ability to compete with others who may have superior resources in specific technology domains. We may experience difficulties or delays in the research, development, production and/or marketing of new products and services which may negatively impact our operating results and prevent us from recouping or realizing a return on the investments required to continue to bring new products and services to market. Further, investment in a product or service could divert our attention and resources from other projects that become more commercially viable in the market. We must anticipate and respond to market and technological changes driven by broader trends such as decarbonization and electrification efforts and the use of low global warming potential refrigerants in response to climate change. Market growth from the use of cleaner energy sources, as well as emissions management, energy efficiency, lower greenhouse gas refrigerant usage, and decarbonization efforts are likely to depend in part on technologies not yet deployed or widely adopted today. We may not adequately innovate or position our business for the adoption of technologies such as battery storage solutions, hydrogen use cases in industry, mobility, and power generation, enhanced electrical grid demand management, carbon capture and sequestration or advanced nuclear power. These trends and the relative competitiveness of our product and service offerings will continue to be impacted by uncertain factors such as the pace of technological developments and related cost considerations, the levels of economic growth in different markets around the world and the adoption of climate change-related policies such as carbon taxes, greenhouse gas emission reductions, incentives or mandates for particular types of energy, or policies that impact the availability of financing for certain types of projects.

Subsubsection Title: Any failure to obtain, maintain, protect or enforce our intellectual property and other proprietary rights, could harm our competitive position and our business.
Subsubsection Text: Our success depends in part on our ability to obtain, maintain, protect and enforce our intellectual property and other proprietary rights. We rely on a combination of patent, copyright, trademark and trade secret laws, as well as certain contractual rights, such as confidentiality and invention assignment agreements with employees and third parties, and license and other agreements with consultants, vendors and customers. However, these laws and agreements provide only limited protection and may not be adequate to protect any of our intellectual property rights from being challenged, invalidated, circumvented, infringed, diluted or misappropriated. Further, efforts to monitor the infringement, misappropriation or other violation of our intellectual property rights by third parties are difficult, expensive, and time-consuming, and there can be no assurance that we will be able to prevent infringing products from being manufactured without our knowledge and consent. We rely on our trademarks, service marks, trade names and brand names to distinguish our services and solutions from those of our competitors. We have registered or applied to register many of these trademarks, but our trademark applications may not mature to registration or we may not be able to otherwise obtain adequate trademark protection. Also, third parties have brought, and may in the future bring opposition, cancellation or similar adversarial proceedings against our trademark registrations and applications, or otherwise challenge our use of our trademarks. In the event that our trademarks are successfully challenged, we could be forced to rebrand our products, which could result in loss of brand recognition and could require us to devote resources to develop, advertise and market new brands. We have applied for, and may continue to apply for, patents relating to our solutions and technology. The patenting process is expensive and time-consuming, and we may not be able to file and/or prosecute all necessary or desirable patent applications at a reasonable cost or in a timely manner or pursue or obtain patent protection in all relevant markets. When we do apply for patents, we cannot assure you that our applications will be successful and result in the issuance of any patents or that the scope of the patents that do issue will provide adequate protection from competition. Furthermore, because the issuance of a patent is not conclusive as to its inventorship, scope, validity or enforceability, it is possible that patents issued to us may be challenged successfully and narrowed in scope or found to be invalid or unenforceable in the future. We also rely upon trade secrets and other proprietary information to protect our products and technology, including in cases where intellectual property may not be registrable, or we believe intellectual property is best ----- protected by means that do not require public disclosure. For example, our proprietary scroll machining technology, which we believe is a key component to maintaining a competitive advantage in the scroll compressor market, is primarily protected as a trade secret. However, trade secret protection is risky and uncertain, and the disclosure or independent development of our proprietary technology could have a material adverse impact on our business and results of operations. We seek to protect our trade secrets and other proprietary information through confidentiality and invention assignment agreements with our employees and third parties, as well as through other security measures. However, these agreements and security measures may be inadequate to protect our trade secrets and other proprietary information. We cannot guarantee that we have entered into such agreements with every party that has or may have had access to our trade secrets or other proprietary information and, even if entered into, these agreements may be breached or otherwise fail to effectively prevent disclosure of trade secrets or other proprietary information, may be limited as to their term and may not provide an adequate remedy in the event of unauthorized disclosure or use of trade secrets or other proprietary information. We have limited control over the protection of trade secrets used by our third-party manufacturers and suppliers and could lose future trade secret protection if any unauthorized disclosure of such information occurs. Further, enforcing a claim that a party illegally disclosed or misappropriated a trade secret is difficult, expensive and time-consuming, and a favorable outcome is not guaranteed. In addition, if any of our trade secrets or other proprietary information were lawfully obtained or independently developed by a third party, we would not have legal recourse to prevent such third party, or those to whom they communicate such technology or information, from using that technology or information to compete with us. Our intellectual property rights and the enforcement or defense of such rights may be affected by developments or uncertainty in laws and regulations relating to intellectual property rights. Moreover, many companies have encountered significant problems in protecting and defending intellectual property rights in foreign jurisdictions. The legal systems of certain countries, particularly certain developing countries, do not favor the enforcement of patents, trade secrets and other intellectual property protection, which could make it difficult for us to stop the infringement, misappropriation or other violation of our intellectual property or marketing of competing products in violation of our intellectual property rights generally. If we do not obtain sufficient protection for our intellectual property, or if we are unable to effectively maintain, protect or enforce our intellectual property rights, our competitiveness could be impaired, which would limit our growth and future revenue. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We may become involved in lawsuits to protect or enforce our intellectual property rights, which could be expensive, time consuming, and unsuccessful, and any claims that we infringe, misappropriate or otherwise violate third parties’ intellectual property rights could have a material and adverse effect on our business.
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, legal action by us may be necessary to protect and enforce our intellectual property and other proprietary rights, which could be costly, time-consuming and distracting to management. Furthermore, our efforts to enforce our intellectual property rights may be met with defenses, counterclaims, and countersuits attacking the validity, scope and enforceability of our intellectual property rights, which could result in the impairment or loss of portions of our intellectual property. We have in the past, and may in the future, be subject to claims by third parties alleging that we have infringed, misappropriated or otherwise violated their intellectual property rights. Furthermore, we cannot guarantee that the operation of our business does not and will not infringe or violate the rights of third parties. Any litigation or proceedings to defend ourselves against allegations of infringement, misappropriation, or other violations of intellectual property rights, regardless of merit, could be costly, divert attention of management and may not ultimately be resolved in our favor. If we are unable to successfully defend against claims that we have infringed the intellectual property rights of others, we may be prevented from using certain intellectual property or offering certain products, or may be liable for damages, which in turn could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations. We may also be required to acquire or develop an alternative, noninfringing product, which could be costly, time-consuming or impossible, or seek a license from a third party, which may not be available on terms that are favorable to us, or at all. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. -----

Subsubsection Title: We may engage in acquisitions, divestitures or other strategic transactions, which are subject to domestic and foreign regulatory requirements, and may encounter difficulties in integrating, separating and managing these businesses and therefore we may not realize the anticipated benefits.
Subsubsection Text: We may enter into acquisitions or other strategic transactions, including partnerships, joint ventures or strategic alliances, as well as evaluate our portfolio for potential divestitures. These activities require favorable environments to execute these transactions, and we may encounter difficulties in obtaining the necessary regulatory approvals in both domestic and foreign jurisdictions. In addition, competition for strategic transactions in the industries in which we operate has escalated during recent years, and may increase costs of such transactions or cause us to refrain from entering into certain such transactions. There can be no assurance that we will identify or successfully complete transactions with suitable candidates in the future, that we will consummate these transactions at rates similar to the past or that completed transactions will be successful.
