Subsubsection Title: The lenders under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities have the discretion to release any guarantor under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities in a variety of circumstances, which will cause such guarantor to be released from its guarantee of the notes offered hereby and the Existing Notes, in which case any liens on the assets of such guarantor in favor of the Senior Secured Credit Facilities, the notes offered hereby and the Existing Notes will also be released.
Subsubsection Text: While any obligations under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities remain outstanding, a guarantor’s guarantee of the notes may be released without action by, or consent of, any holder of the notes or the trustee under the indenture that will govern the notes, at the discretion of lenders under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities, if the guarantor no longer guarantees obligations under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities or any other indebtedness, in which case any liens on the assets of such guarantor in favor of the Senior Secured Credit Facilities, the Existing Notes and the notes offered hereby. See “Description of Notes.” The lenders under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities will have the discretion to release the guarantees under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities in a variety of circumstances. You will not have a claim as a creditor against any subsidiary that is no longer a guarantor of the ----- notes, and the indebtedness and other liabilities, including trade payables, whether secured or unsecured, of those non-guarantor subsidiaries will be structurally senior to claims of noteholders.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Indebtedness and the Notes
Subsubsection Title: There are circumstances other than repayment or discharge of the notes under which the guarantees will be released automatically, without your consent or the consent of the trustee.
Subsubsection Text: Under various circumstances, the guarantees of the notes will be released automatically. The guarantee of a subsidiary guarantor of the notes will be automatically released to the extent such subsidiary guarantor is released in connection with a sale or other disposition of the equity interests of such subsidiary guarantor in a transaction not prohibited by the indenture that will govern the notes. The indenture also will permit us to designate one or more of the Issuer’s restricted subsidiaries that is a guarantor of the notes as an unrestricted subsidiary, which will result in the guarantee of such subsidiary guarantor being automatically released. If a subsidiary guarantor is released from its guarantee of the Term Loan Facilities or the Revolving Credit Facility or certain other indebtedness of the Issuers or any other guarantor, other than in connection with a refinancing of the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and such other indebtedness or a payment under such guarantee, or a guarantor ceases to be a subsidiary as a result of any foreclosure of any pledge or security interest securing the secured indebtedness, such subsidiary’s guarantee of the notes offered hereby and the Existing Notes will be automatically released as well, in which case any liens on the assets of such subsidiary in favor of the Term Loan Facilities or the Revolving Credit Facility, as applicable, and the notes offered hereby and the Existing Notes will also be released. If the guarantee of any subsidiary guarantor is released, no holder of the notes will have a claim as a creditor against that subsidiary, and the indebtedness and other liabilities, including trade payables and preferred stock, if any, whether secured or unsecured, of that subsidiary will be structurally senior to the claim of any holders of the notes. For a description of all circumstances in which a guarantor’s subsidiary guarantee will be automatically released, see “Description of Notes—Guarantees.” In addition, the guarantee by Holdings, and the pledge by Holdings of the Issuer’s equity, will be automatically and unconditionally released if Holdings ceases to be the direct parent of the Issuer, including upon a merger, consolidation or sale. See “Description of Notes—Guarantees.”

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Indebtedness and the Notes
Subsubsection Title: There are circumstances, other than the repayment or discharge of the notes, under which the Collateral and the guarantees will be released automatically, without your consent or the consent of the Notes Collateral Agent, and you may not realize any payment upon the release of such Collateral.
Subsubsection Text: Under various circumstances, the Collateral and guarantees will be released automatically, including: - upon a sale, transfer or other disposition of such Collateral (to a person that is not the Issuers or a guarantor) in a transaction not prohibited under the indenture that will govern the notes. See “Description of Notes—Release of Collateral”; - with respect to the equity interests of and Collateral held by a guarantor of the notes, upon the release of such guarantor from its guarantees; - pursuant to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreements, upon any release in connection with a foreclosure or exercise of remedies with respect to such Collateral by the controlling collateral agent in accordance with the terms of the Intercreditor Agreements; - upon the release of Excess Proceeds that remain unexpended after the conclusion of an Asset Sale Offer conducted in accordance with the Indenture that will govern the notes (each capitalized term as defined under the heading “Description of Notes”); - (x) if all other liens on such Collateral securing Equal Priority Obligations are released or will be released simultaneously therewith (other than any release by, or as a result of, payment of the Equal Priority Obligations) and (y) in the case of ABL Priority Collateral securing Senior ABL Revolving Credit Obligations then outstanding, if the liens on such ABL Priority Collateral securing Senior ABL Revolving Credit Obligations are released or will be released simultaneously therewith by the Senior ----- ABL Credit Agreement Collateral Agent or otherwise pursuant to the Senior ABL Credit Agreement (other than any release by, or as a result of, payment of the Senior ABL Revolving Credit Obligations); - if the release of such lien is approved, authorized or ratified by the required number of holders; - to the extent such Collateral becomes an Excluded Asset (as defined under the heading “Description of Notes”); and - if the notes would be rated investment grade by either Moody’s or S&P after giving effect to such lien release. See “Description of Notes—Release of Collateral.” The indenture that will govern the notes will also permit us to designate one or more of the Issuer’s restricted subsidiaries that is a guarantor of the notes as an unrestricted subsidiary. If the Issuers designate a subsidiary guarantor as an unrestricted subsidiary for purposes of the indenture that will govern the notes, all of the liens on the equity interests of and any Collateral owned by that subsidiary or any of its subsidiaries and any guarantees of the notes by that subsidiary or any of its subsidiaries will be released under the indenture that will govern the notes. Designation of an unrestricted subsidiary will reduce the aggregate value of the Collateral securing the notes to the extent that liens on the assets of the unrestricted subsidiary and its subsidiaries are released. In addition, the creditors of any such unrestricted subsidiary and its subsidiaries will have a claim on the assets of the unrestricted subsidiary and its subsidiaries senior to the claim of the holders of the notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Indebtedness and the Notes
Subsubsection Title: We are not and will not be subject to the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002.
Subsubsection Text: We are not subject to the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 (the “Sarbanes-Oxley Act”). Since we have not registered the Existing Notes and will not register the notes under the Securities Act after this offering, we will not be subject to the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, which requires public companies to have and maintain effective disclosure controls and procedures to ensure timely disclosure of material information, and have management review the effectiveness of those controls on a quarterly basis. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act also requires public companies to have and maintain effective internal controls over financial reporting to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and preparation of financial statements, and have management review the effectiveness of those controls on an annual basis (and have the independent auditor attest to the effectiveness of such internal controls). We will not be required to comply with these requirements and therefore we may not have comparable procedures in place as compared to other public companies.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Indebtedness and the Notes
Subsubsection Title: If the Liens securing the notes are released as a result of an Investment Grade Event, as defined under the heading “Description of Notes,” the notes will become unsecured and no Liens will be granted unless the Notes have a lower than investment grade rating from each of Moody’s and S&P.
Subsubsection Text: If the Liens securing the notes are released as a result of an Investment Grade Event, the notes will become unsecured and no Liens will be granted unless the Notes have a lower than investment grade rating from each of Moody’s and S&P. Any pledge of collateral in favor of the Notes Collateral Agent and the other security documents delivered after such date, could be avoidable in bankruptcy and if this were to occur, holders of the notes could lose the benefit of such security interest. See “—Any future pledge of Collateral or guarantee may be avoidable in bankruptcy.”

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Indebtedness and the Notes
Subsubsection Title: In the event that the Seller Notes Repurchase is not consummated on or before the Outside Date and the other Escrow Release Conditions are not satisfied or the terms of the Escrow Agreement are not otherwise complied with, the notes will be subject to a Special Mandatory Redemption, and as a result, you may not obtain the return you expect on the notes.
Subsubsection Text: If the Seller Notes Repurchase is not consummated simultaneously with this offering, concurrently with the closing of this offering, the Issuers will enter into the Escrow Agreement pursuant to which the Issuer will deposit (or cause to be deposited) an amount equal to the gross proceeds of the offering into an escrow account for the notes until the date that the Escrow Release Conditions are satisfied. The funds in the escrow account will be initially ----- limited to the gross proceeds from the offering and will not be sufficient to pay the Special Mandatory Redemption Price. If, among other things, the Seller Notes Repurchase is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date, the Issuers will redeem, on the Special Mandatory Redemption Date in accordance with the terms of the indenture that will govern the notes, all of the notes at the Special Mandatory Redemption Price. Upon such redemption, you may not be able to reinvest the proceeds from the redemption in an investment that yields comparable returns. Additionally, you may suffer a loss on your investment if you purchase the notes at a price greater than the issue price of the notes. See “Description of Notes—Escrow of Gross Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.” The ability of the holders of the notes to realize upon the funds of the escrow account may be subject to certain bankruptcy law limitations in the event of a bankruptcy of the Issuers.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Indebtedness and the Notes
Subsubsection Title: Between the time of the offering of the notes and the consummation of the Seller Notes Repurchase, the parties to the Note Purchase Agreement may agree to modify or waive the terms or conditions of such document without consent of the holders of notes.
Subsubsection Text: Prior to the consummation of the Seller Notes Repurchase, the parties to the Note Purchase Agreement may agree to amendments or waivers of the terms thereof. Although the Escrow Agreement will provide as a condition to the release of the funds in the escrow account that the Seller Notes Repurchase is to be consummated, this condition will not preclude the transaction parties from making changes to the terms of the transaction or from waiving conditions to the transaction that have an adverse effect on the holders of the notes, including a change in the purchase price or to the structure of the Seller Notes Repurchase.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Indebtedness and the Notes
Subsubsection Title: If the Issuers commence a bankruptcy or reorganization case or one is commenced against the Issuers, bankruptcy laws may prevent the release of the escrowed funds.
Subsubsection Text: If the Issuers commence a bankruptcy or reorganization case, or one is commenced against the Issuers, while amounts remain in the escrow account, applicable bankruptcy laws may prevent the Escrow Agent from releasing the funds in the escrow account or applying those funds to effect a Special Mandatory Redemption of the notes or otherwise applying those funds for the benefit of itself and the holders of the notes. The court adjudicating that case might find that the escrow account is the property of the bankruptcy estate. Although the amounts in the escrow account will be pledged as collateral for payment, if required, of the Special Mandatory Redemption Price of the notes, the automatic stay provisions of the federal bankruptcy laws generally prohibit secured creditors from foreclosing upon or disposing of a debtor’s property without bankruptcy court approval. As a result, holders of the notes may not be able to have the funds in the escrow account applied at the time or in the manner contemplated by the indenture that will govern the notes and could suffer a loss as a result. In addition, if the court adjudicating the Issuers’ bankruptcy or reorganization case finds that the escrowed funds are property of the bankruptcy estate, the court could authorize the use of these funds by the bankruptcy estate or the bankruptcy trustee, if one is appointed, with or without restrictions. As a result, the holders of the notes could become unsecured creditors of the bankruptcy estate. In such event, the only remedy available to the holders of the notes would be to sue for payment on such notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Indebtedness and the Notes
Subsubsection Title: We cannot assure you that the procedures for book-entry interests to be implemented through DTC will be adequate to ensure the timely exercise of your rights under the notes.
Subsubsection Text: Unless and until notes in definitive registered form are issued in exchange for global notes, owners of book-entry interests will not be considered owners or holders of the notes except in the limited circumstances provided in the indenture governing such notes. DTC (or its nominee), will be the sole registered holder of the global notes representing the applicable notes. After payment to DTC, we will have no responsibility or liability for the payment of interest, principal, or other amounts to the owners of book-entry interests. Accordingly, if you own a book-entry interest, you must rely on the procedures of DTC, and if you are not a participant in DTC, on the ----- procedures of the participant through which you own your interest, to exercise any rights and obligations of a holder under the indenture governing such notes. See “Book Entry, Delivery and Form.” Unlike the holders of the notes themselves, owners of book-entry interests will not have the direct right to act upon our solicitations for consents, requests for waivers, or other actions from holders of the notes. Instead, if you own a book-entry interest, you will be permitted to act only to the extent you have received appropriate proxies to do so from DTC. There can be no assurance that procedures implemented for the granting of such proxies will be sufficient to enable you to vote on any request actions on a timely basis. Similarly, upon the occurrence of an event of default under the indenture that will govern the notes, if you own a book-entry interest, you will be restricted to acting through DTC. We cannot assure you that the procedures to be implemented through DTC will be adequate to ensure the timely exercise of rights under the notes. See “Book Entry, Delivery and Form.”

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Indebtedness and the Notes
Subsubsection Title: Holder of the notes may not be able to effect service of process or enforce judgments obtained against us outside of the United States.
Subsubsection Text: The Issuers and the guarantors are organized under the laws of the United States. A substantial portion of our assets are located in the United States and, as a result, it may not be possible for investors to effect service of process or enforce judgments obtained against us outside the United States. -----

_An investment in the notes involves a high degree of risk. You should carefully consider the risks described below and all of the information included in this offering memorandum before deciding whether to purchase the notes. Any of the following risks may materially and adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. The risks and uncertainties described below are not the only risks and uncertainties that we face. Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to us or that we currently deem immaterial may also materially and adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. In such a case, you may lose all or part of your original investment. The risks discussed below also include forward-looking statements, and our actual results may differ substantially from those discussed in these forward-looking statements. See “Special Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” in this offering memorandum._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading global manufacturer of mission critical compressors, controls, components and solutions to the HVACR market. We provide products that help enhance human health and comfort, protect food quality and safety, advance energy efficiency, and create an environmentally sustainable infrastructure. Key components in an HVACR ecosystem include the compressor, controls, the condenser and the evaporator. We provide best-in-class compressors, controls, components and solutions for residential, commercial, industrial and transportation applications. We are the largest global manufacturer in our served markets with approximately 40% share in overall global compression, including approximately 70% in the North America residential HVAC segment, and strong positions within our non-compression offerings. Our large installed base of more than 150 million HVAC compressor units globally drives profitable aftermarket sales due to replacement dynamics, with approximately 80% of our net sales tied to repair or replacement activity. Ongoing technology leadership is a key driver of our ability to capitalize on the replacement ----- cycle, as each successive generation of compressor provides greater cost savings, energy efficiency and higher levels of environmental sustainability impact. We serve our customers through 27 global manufacturing facilities and 12 major global ER&D centers, with a global headcount of approximately 18,000 employees. Global scale paired with localized manufacturing enable us to think globally and act locally, creating a flexible and robust supply chain that is regionalized to provide customers with a strong on-time delivery record. This advantage is derived not just from global operations, but also from the breadth of our product offerings and our ability to meet customers’ requirements. Decades of research and customer collaboration have ultimately yielded an unmatched and market leading global HVAC compressor installed base.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The following is a summary of our financial results for the four months ended September 30, 2023 (Successor), eight months ended May 31, 2023 (Predecessor) and the year ended September 30, 2022 (Predecessor): - Net sales were $1,676.9 million and $3,162.3 million for the four months ended September 30, 2023 (Successor) and eight months ended May 31, 2023 (Predecessor), respectively, and $5,060.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2022 (Predecessor). - Net (loss) earnings were $(402.8) million and $441.2 million for the four months ended September 30, 2023 (Successor) and eight months ended May 31, 2023 (Predecessor), respectively, and $740.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2022 (Predecessor). - Adjusted EBITDA was $436.8 million and $800.9 million for the four months ended September 30, 2023 (Successor) and eight months ended May 31, 2023 (Predecessor), respectively, and $1,178.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2022 (Predecessor). - Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA was $1,379.2 million for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023. The following is a summary of our financial results for the six months ended March 31, 2024 (Successor) and the six months ended March 31, 2023 (Predecessor): - Net sales were $2,199.3 million for the six months ended March 31, 2024, and $2,315.7 million for the six months ended March 31, 2023. - Net (loss) earnings were $(276.5) million for the six months ended March 31, 2024, and $307.7 million for the six months ended March 31, 2023. - Adjusted EBITDA was $568.6 million for the six months ended March 31, 2024, and $561.1 million for the six months ended March 31, 2023. - Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA was $1,361.0 million for the trailing twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Company’s businesses are primarily organized by product offering. The Company’s products are organized into two broad categories - HVACR Technologies and Electronics and Controls. Geographically, we organize through three world areas - Americas, Europe and Asia, Middle East and Africa (“AMEA”). The served applications include, among others, heating and cooling including heat pump applications, food service / retail / industrial refrigeration, perishable goods, transportation, healthcare / life sciences, and renewable energy. The Company’s compression technologies enable higher efficiency in commercial and residential HVAC units, as well as in commercial and industrial refrigeration units. The Company also has a solution portfolio that ----- manages, monitors and controls refrigeration units in the commercial setting, as well as software solutions that measure and monitor temperature conditions of refrigerated goods in transit. The Company’s industrial products are designed into renewable energy processes including RNG and Biogas applications. In general, the company’s technologies and solutions address global trends, including (i) the decarbonization and increased energy efficiency of heating, cooling, refrigeration and industrial processes, (ii) the drive towards lower-GWP refrigerants and (iii) the efficient transport of perishable goods including food and medicine. The Company now operates under the Copeland brand, as well as the Sensi, Verdant, Vilter and White-Rodgers sub-brands.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: The Transactions—the Acquisition and Financing Transactions
Subsubsection Text: On October 30, 2022, the Company entered into a Transaction Agreement (“Transaction Agreement”) with Emerson Electric Co. (“Emerson”), BCP Emerald Aggregator L.P. (“BCP”) and Merger Sub, whereby BCP agreed to purchase, and Emerson agreed to sell, equity interests in JV NewCo following the Restructuring (as defined below), for a purchase price of $13,647 million. Emerald JV Holdings L.P. (“Emerald” or “JV NewCo” or “the Company” or “Copeland”), a Delaware limited partnership, was formed by Emerson to hold its Climate Technology Business (“Climate Technologies” or “CT”) in connection with the acquisition of a majority stake in Climate Technologies (the “Acquisition”) by certain investment funds affiliated with Blackstone Inc. (“Blackstone”). The Company currently holds Climate Technologies after the completion of certain restructuring steps undertaken by Emerson to transfer Climate Technologies to JV NewCo (the “Restructuring”). The Acquisition was consummated on May 31, 2023 (the “Acquisition Date”). The Acquisition was accounted for as a business combination under Accounting Standards Codification 805, Business Combinations. The purchase consideration was allocated to the identifiable assets and liabilities of Copeland measured at their fair value as of the effective date of the Acquisition. Any excess of the purchase consideration over the fair value of the identifiable assets and liabilities of Copeland was recognized as goodwill in our consolidated financial statements as of September 30, 2023 (Successor). As a result of the Acquisition, we expect to incur higher depreciation, amortization, interest expense and higher cost of goods sold due to stepped up inventory as compared to the Predecessor periods. The Successor Statement of Operations reflects the results of the business following the closing of the Acquisition. However, on May 19, 2023, Emerald Debt Merger Sub L.L.C (“Merger Sub”), a subsidiary of Emerald JV Holdings, L.P., which was merged with and into EMRLD Borrower LP (“EMRLD Borrower”) on the consummation of the Acquisition, and Emerald Co-Issuer Inc., a direct subsidiary of EMRLD Borrower, issued senior secured notes in the aggregate principal amount of $2,275.0 million and aggregate principal amount of €455.0 million (or $500.0 million U.S. dollar equivalent, based on the exchange rate of approximately $1.10 per €1.00), (the “Original Dollar Notes” and the “Original Euro Notes”, respectively, and collectively the “Initial Notes”). The Company incurred $6.2 million of interest expense for the period from May 19, 2023, to May 31, 2023, related to the Initial Notes, which has been recognized in the Successor Period. In addition to the Initial Notes, in connection with the Acquisition, on May 31, 2023, EMRLD Borrower entered into a 5-year senior secured term loan facility in an original aggregate principal amount of $450.0 million (the “Term Loan A Facility”) and a 7-year senior secured term loan facility in an original aggregate principal amount of $2,275.0 million (the “Original Term Loan B Facility” and, together with the Term Loan A Facility, the “Term Loan Facilities”), and a 5-year senior secured asset-based revolving credit facility in an aggregate principal amount of up to $700.0 million (the “Revolving Credit Facility” and, together with the Term Loan Facilities, the “Senior Secured Credit Facilities”). As of March 31, 2024, the Company has $399.5 million of borrowing availability under the Revolving Credit Facility subject to borrowing base capacity (including borrowing base capacity in foreign jurisdictions after giving effect to approximately $9.1 million of letters of credit expected to be outstanding thereunder), in each case, before giving effect to financing costs. Further, EMRLD Seller Notes Issuer L.P., an entity owned by the Company, issued two senior unsecured notes to subsidiaries of Emerson in the aggregate amount of $2,250.0 million (the “Seller Notes”). The borrowers/issuers under the Term Loan Facilities, the Initial Notes, Revolving Credit Facility, and the Seller Notes (collectively, the “Financing Transactions” and, together with the Acquisition, the “Transactions”) are wholly owned subsidiaries of the Company. Accordingly, in periods after the Acquisition, we have recorded an increase in interest expense. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: The Term Loan B Facility Refinancing and New Notes Issuance
Subsubsection Text: On February 6, 2024, EMRLD Borrower entered into an amendment to the Credit Agreement governing the Term Loan Facilities, which provided for the incurrence of a new senior secured term “B” loan (the “Refinanced Term Loan B Facility”) in an aggregate principal amount of $1,519.3 million. The Refinanced Term Loan B Facility has identical terms to the Original Term Loan B Facility provided, however, that (a) borrowings under the Refinanced Term Loan B Facility bear interest at the Term SOFR Rate plus a margin of between 2.25% and 2.50% per annum (based on EMRLD Borrower’s first lien net leverage ratio), subject to a Term SOFR Rate floor of 0.00% and (b) any voluntary prepayment, refinancing or repricing of the term loans under the Refinanced Term Loan B Facility in connection with certain repricing transactions that occur on or prior to the six-month anniversary of the closing of the Refinanced Term Loan B Facility are subject to a prepayment premium of 1.00% of the principal amount of such term loans so prepaid, refinanced or repriced, subject to certain exceptions. In connection with the Refinanced Term Loan B Facility, on February 6, 2024, the Company issued new senior secured notes in the aggregate principal amount of $750.0 million, including $500.0 million of Dollar Notes (the “New Dollar Notes”) and €230.0 (or $250.0 million U.S. dollar equivalent, based on the exchange rate of approximately $1.09 per €1.00) of Euro Notes (the “New Euro Notes” and, collectively with the New Dollar Notes, the “New Notes”). The proceeds of the Refinanced Term Loan B Facility, together with the proceeds of the New Notes and cash on hand were used to refinance all of the Original Term Loan B Facility and to pay fees, costs and expenses related to the offering of the New Notes and the Refinanced Term Loan B Facility. The New Dollar Notes were issued at a premium of 100.750, resulting in a premium of $3.8 million. The New Euro Notes were issued at a premium of 104.250, resulting in a USD premium of approximately $10.6 million. The New Notes have the same terms as the Initial Notes.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Separation from Emerson and operating as a standalone company
Subsubsection Text: Following the Acquisition, Copeland is a standalone company with independent functions and operations. However, prior to the Acquisition and Financing Transactions, see “—Comparability of Historical Financial Results—The Acquisition and Financing Transactions,” the Climate Technologies Business historically operated as part of Emerson and not as a standalone entity. The Predecessor period of each of the (i) consolidated and combined financial statements and (ii) unaudited condensed, consolidated and combined financial statements and this section present the historical financial position, results of operations and cash flows of the Climate Technologies Business as if it had operated on a standalone basis subject to Emerson’s control and include all accounts of the Climate Technologies Business and its subsidiaries and affiliates on a consolidated basis. Intercompany transactions, profits and balances among Climate Technologies Business entities have been eliminated in consolidation and combination. The Predecessor period of each of the (i) consolidated and combined financial statements and (ii) unaudited condensed, consolidated and combined financial statements were derived from Emerson’s financial statements and accounting records and have been prepared in conformity with GAAP. Sale and purchase transactions between the Climate Technologies Business and other Emerson affiliates are included in the unaudited condensed and consolidated financial statements for the six months ended March 31, 2024 (Successor), the audited condensed and consolidated financial statements as of September 30, 2023 (Successor) and for the four months ended September 30, 2023 (Successor), the consolidated and combined financial statements as of September 30, 2022 (Predecessor) and for the eight months ended May 31, 2023 (Predecessor) and the year ended September 30, 2022 (Predecessor), as well as the unaudited condensed, consolidated and combined financial statements for the six months ended March 31, 2023 (Predecessor). As a business of Emerson, the Climate Technologies Business was charged for costs directly related to its business and was allocated a portion of Emerson’s general corporate costs. All of these costs were reflected in the Predecessor period of the each of the (i) consolidated and combined financial statements and (ii) unaudited condensed, consolidated and combined financial statements. The Climate Technologies Business participated in various Emerson programs which included information technology services, employee benefits, medical insurance and other programs. Costs associated with these programs were charged to the Climate Technologies Business based on Emerson’s actual cost and the Climate Technologies Business’ relative level of usage. Emerson provided certain oversight and support services, including assistance with management strategy, logistics, marketing, finance, treasury, insurance, tax, human resources, legal, compliance and other activities. A charge for these services and royalties was allocated to the Climate Technologies Business based principally on ----- revenue. While management believes the methodologies and assumptions used to allocate these costs are reasonable, each of the (i) consolidated and combined financial statements and (ii) unaudited condensed, consolidated and combined financial statements for the Predecessor periods do not purport to represent the financial position, or the results of operations, changes in equity, and cash flows of the Climate Technologies Business as a standalone entity, or what they would have been had the Climate Technologies Business operated as a standalone entity during the periods presented. Income tax expense was recorded as if the Climate Technologies Business filed tax returns on a stand-alone basis separate from Emerson. This separate return methodology applies the accounting guidance for income taxes to the consolidated and combined carve-out financial statements as if the Climate Technologies Business was a standalone enterprise for the periods presented. Our operating results were included in Emerson’s consolidated U.S. federal and state income tax returns or non-U.S. jurisdiction tax returns. The calculation of the Climate Technologies Business’ income taxes involved considerable judgment and the use of both estimates and allocations that affect the calculation of certain tax liabilities and the determination of the recoverability of certain deferred tax assets, which arise from temporary differences between the tax and financial statement recognition of revenue and expenses. Therefore, the tax liabilities and deferred taxes included in each of the (i) unaudited condensed, consolidated and combined financial statements as of March 31, 2023 (Predecessor) and for the six months ended March 31, 2023 (Predecessor) and (ii) consolidated and combined financial statements as of September 30, 2022 (Predecessor) and the eight months ended May 31, 2023 (Predecessor) and the year ended September 30, 2022 (Predecessor) may not be reflective of our actual tax balances that were included in Emerson’s consolidated filings prior to the carve-out.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors and Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Competitive Landscape
Subsubsection Text: We operate in markets that are highly competitive and potentially volatile, and we compete on the basis of product performance, quality, service and/or price across the industries and markets served. Our operations are significantly dependent on the current and future business environment, including capital and consumer spending. A significant element of our competitive strategy is to deliver solutions to our customers by manufacturing highquality products at the best relevant global cost. Various companies compete with us in one or more product lines and the number of competitors varies by product line. Some of our competitors have substantially greater sales, assets and financial resources than our Company, allowing them to invest in more extensive research and development and/or marketing activity and making them better able to withstand adverse market conditions, and we also compete with many smaller companies. There has been consolidation and new entrants (including nontraditional competitors) within our industry and there may be future consolidation and new entrants which could result in increased competition and significantly alter the dynamics of the competitive landscape in which we operate.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors and Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Constant Innovation
Subsubsection Text: The success of new and improved products and services depends on their initial and continued acceptance by our customers. Our business is affected by varying degrees of technological change and corresponding shifts in customer demand, which result in unpredictable product transitions, shortened life cycles and increased importance of being first to market with new products and services. We may experience difficulties or delays in the research, development, production and/or marketing of new products and services which may negatively impact our operating results and prevent us from recouping or realizing a return on the investments required to continue to bring new products and services to market. As a result of our research and development efforts, we hold intellectual property rights that are important to our business and include numerous patents, trademarks, copyrights, trade secrets and other confidential information. This intellectual property may be subject to challenge, infringement, invalidation or circumvention by third parties. Despite extensive security measures, our intellectual property may be subject to misappropriation through unauthorized access of our information technology systems, employee theft, or other acts of industrial ----- espionage. Should the Company be unable to adequately defend or protect its intellectual property, it may suffer competitive harm.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors and Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Raw Materials & Components
Subsubsection Text: Our major requirements for raw materials include steel, copper, cast iron, electronics, aluminum, brass and, to a lesser extent, plastics and petroleum-based chemicals. We seek multiple sources of supply for each of our major requirements in order to avoid significant dependence on any one or a few suppliers. However, the availability of and prices for raw materials, parts and components may be subject to curtailment or change due to, among other things, suppliers’ allocation to other purchasers, interruptions in production by suppliers, changes in exchange rates and prevailing price levels. In addition, our facilities, supply chains, distribution systems, and products may be impacted by natural or man-made disruptions, including armed conflict, damaging weather or other acts of nature, pandemics or other public health crises or other events.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors and Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Concentration of Revenue
Subsubsection Text: We derive a significant portion of our sales from a limited number of customers, and such concentration may continue in the future. The loss of, or significant reduction in sales to, one or more major customers or groups of customers could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial condition and cash flows. Further, the addition of new major customers in the future could increase our customer concentration risks as described above.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors and Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Economic Conditions
Subsubsection Text: Accelerated and pronounced economic pressures, such as the continuing inflationary cost pressure on labor and the goods and services we rely upon to serve our customers, have had and continue to have a significant impact on our cost structure and capital expenditures. Our sales in the residential and commercial new construction markets correlate to the number of new homes and buildings that are built, which in turn is influenced by cyclical factors such as interest rates, inflation, availability of financing, consumer spending habits and confidence, employment rates and other macroeconomic factors over which we have no control. Significant components of our operating expenses vary directly as we experience a heightened pace of inflation, and we seek to dynamically manage our cost structure using price actions with our customers in response to such changes. Given a portion of our revenue is tied to a contractual lookback provision with respect to price actions, there is a timing lag in our ability to recover increased costs under those contracts during periods of rapid inflation. The contract lag and inability to increase prices real-time to offset increased costs and inflationary pressures, or otherwise mitigate the impact of these macroeconomic conditions and market disruptions on our business, may increase our costs of doing business and reduce our margins in any given period.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors and Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Regulatory Environment
Subsubsection Text: Increased public awareness and concern regarding global climate change may result in more international, federal, and/or state or other stakeholder requirements or expectations that could result in more restrictive or expansive standards, such as stricter limits on greenhouse gas emissions or more prescriptive reporting of environmental, social, and governance metrics. There continues to be a lack of consistent climate change legislation and standards, which creates economic and regulatory uncertainty. Further, these regulatory changes may result in changes in market demand for certain products manufactured and sold by the Company. The impact of these standards may have an impact on the Company’s business, capital expenditures, results of operations, financial condition and competitive position.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors and Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations have been affected by the following factors and trends, which we expect will continue to impact our future results:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Standalone Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin
Subsubsection Text: We define EBITDA as net earnings adjusted for interest expense, net, income tax, depreciation and amortization expense. Adjusted EBITDA is EBITDA as further adjusted to exclude certain items that impact the comparison of the performance of our businesses either period-over-period or with other businesses as more fully described below. Adjusted EBITDA Margin is calculated as Adjusted EBITDA divided by net sales for the respective period. Standalone Adjusted EBITDA is calculated as Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted for standalone costs. We define Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA as Standalone Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted for the estimated normalized “run-rate” benefit from pricing actions and cost saving initiatives that are expected to be realized by the end of fiscal 2026. Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA margin is calculated as Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA divided by net sales for the respective period. We use EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Standalone Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin to compare our operating results on a consistent basis. We present EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Standalone Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin because we believe they assist investors and analysts in comparing our performance across reporting periods on a consistent basis by excluding items that we do not believe are indicative of our core operating performance, and we believe that these metrics provide useful information to investors in understanding and evaluating our operating results. EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Standalone Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin do not reflect certain cash expenses that we are obligated to make, and although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, assets being depreciated and amortized will often have to be replaced in the future, and EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Standalone Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin do not reflect any cash requirements for such replacements. Our non-GAAP financial measures are not meant to be considered superior to or a substitute for the results of operations or cash flow prepared in accordance with GAAP. In addition, our non-GAAP financial measures have limitations associated with their use as compared to the most directly comparable GAAP measures, in that they may be different from, and therefore not comparable to, similar measures used by other companies.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Free Cash Flow and Adjusted Free Cash Flow
Subsubsection Text: We define Free Cash Flow as cash provided by operating activities less capital expenditures. Adjusted Free Cash Flow is Free Cash Flow less partnership distributions. We use Free Cash Flow and Adjusted Free Cash Flow to evaluate our ability to generate cash that can be used for working capital requirements, interest, repayment of indebtedness, member distributions, acquisitions, and for continued re-investment into our business.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We use various non-GAAP financial metrics to analyze and evaluate the performance of our business and to provide a greater understanding with respect to our results of operations. These include EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Standalone Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Free Cash Flow and Adjusted Free Cash Flow. ----- Certain of these key performance measures are not measurements of financial performance under GAAP. In evaluating our performance as measured by these non-GAAP measures, management recognizes and considers the limitations of these measures. Other companies in our industry may calculate them differently than we do, or may not calculate them at all, limiting their usefulness as comparative measures. Because of these limitations, these non-GAAP measures should not be considered in isolation or as substitutes for net income or any other measure calculated in accordance with GAAP, as applicable, and should be considered together with GAAP financial measures.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Net sales
Subsubsection Text: We generate revenue principally from the sales of manufactured products. Revenue is recognized with the transfer of control which is generally when a product is shipped to a customer, the customer has legal title to the product, and the Company has a right to payment for such product. Although products are generally sold at fixed prices, certain arrangements include rebates, cash discounts or penalties which are accounted for as variable ----- consideration. The Company records a reduction to revenue at the time of sale to reflect the ultimate amount of consideration it expects to receive. The Company’s estimates are updated quarterly and based on historical experience, trend analysis, and expected market conditions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Cost of sales
Subsubsection Text: Cost of sales consists of product costs, including the cost of materials, direct and indirect labor costs, overhead, certain depreciation, shipping and handling costs and import expenses.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Selling, general and administrative expenses
Subsubsection Text: Selling, general and administrative (“SG&A”) expenses consist of corporate management and support functions, including general management, legal, accounting, finance, human resources, sales, marketing, and other functions not directly associated with revenue generation activities. SG&A expenses include salaries, bonuses and other payroll-related benefits, general operating expenses such as occupancy costs, information technology infrastructure, travel, freight out, advertising and marketing expenses, as well as professional services and consulting expenses.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Transaction and separation expenses
Subsubsection Text: Transaction and separation expenses are predominantly associated with the Acquisition, covering key items such as due-diligence costs, legal fees, advisory charges, breakage fees from standby debt financing, insurance premium costs, real estate transfer taxes, and stand-up costs, inclusive of financial and systems-related advisor fees as well as IT and digital marketing costs, primarily associated with functional advisory and consulting fees to support the company’s separation and stand-up organization post-Acquisition.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Amortization of intangibles
Subsubsection Text: Amortization of intangibles relates to expense associated with acquired customer relationships, developed technology, tradename, backlog, and other definite-lived intangible assets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Other expense (income), net
Subsubsection Text: Other expense (income), net is composed of several items that are individually immaterial including restructuring expense, foreign currency loss (gain), and other items.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Interest (expense) income, net
Subsubsection Text: Interest (expense) income, net consists primarily of accrued interest on third-party and related party debt obligations and related amortization of debt discounts, premiums and deferred issuance costs, as well as interest income from third party deposits and related party debt.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Income tax benefit (expense)
Subsubsection Text: Effective in the Successor period, substantially all U.S. operations are owned by an entity treated as a partnership for U.S. tax purposes, which generally is not subject to U.S. income tax. Refer to Note 6 to our unaudited condensed and consolidated financial statements for information regarding our tax expense. Prior to the Acquisition, the Company’s operations were included in Emerson’s combined US and non-US income tax returns in most locations. As such, income tax expense was calculated following the separate return method, which applies ASC 740, Income Taxes, as if the Company was a stand-alone enterprise and a separate taxpayer in each jurisdiction for the periods presented. The calculation requires considerable judgement and as a result, the Company’s deferred income tax rate and deferred tax balances may differ from those in Emerson’s historical results. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Six months ended March 31, 2024 (Successor) compared to six months ended March 31, 2023 (Predecessor) Successor** **Predecessor Six months ended** **Six months ended March 31, 2024** **March 31, 2023** **$ Change** **% Change

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Net (loss) earnings attributable to Emerald JV
Subsubsection Title: Net sales
Subsubsection Text: Net sales were $2,199.3 million for the six months ended March 31, 2024 (Successor) and $2,315.7 million for the six months ended March 31, 2023 (Predecessor). The net sales decline of 5% year-over-year reflected an approximately 6% decrease in volumes offset by an approximately 1% increase in net pricing driven by falling commodity costs and higher sales prices. Regionally, Europe net sales were down 30%, AMEA net sales were down 3% and Americas net sales were down 1%. Overall, volume softness was driven by channel inventory normalization and global economic headwinds. ----- Net sales were $5,060.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2022 (Predecessor), an increase of $599.7 million, or 13.4%, compared to $4,460.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2021 (Predecessor). Underlying sales were up approximately 14.8%, largely reflecting the impact of 10.6% from higher prices and 4.2% from higher volume, while foreign currency translation had a 1.4% unfavorable impact.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Net (loss) earnings attributable to Emerald JV
Subsubsection Title: Cost of sales
Subsubsection Text: Cost of sales were $1,442.2 million for the six months ended March 31, 2024 (Successor) and $1,543.4 million for the six months ended March 31, 2023 (Predecessor). Gross margin increased by 1.0% year-over-year to 34.4% due to higher sales prices and deflationary impacts on raw materials, partially offset by wage and other inflation deleverage on lower sales volumes. Cost of sales were $3,489.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2022 (Predecessor), an increase of $506.0 million, or 17.0%, compared to $2,983.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2021 (Predecessor), primarily due to higher sales volume and higher materials costs. Gross margin decreased by 2.1 percentage points to 31.0%, as price less net material cost inflation was favorable but had a dilutive impact on margins. Higher freight and other inflation also negatively impacted margins.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Net (loss) earnings attributable to Emerald JV
Subsubsection Title: Selling, general and administrative expenses
Subsubsection Text: Selling, general and administration expenses were $314.0 million for the six months ended March 31, 2024 (Successor) and $320.6 million for the six months ended March 31, 2023 (Predecessor). The overall decrease in fiscal year 2024 was primarily driven by cost control and execution of cost savings initiatives partially offset by stand-alone costs incurred during 2024. Selling, general and administrative expenses were $611.6 million for the year ended September 30, 2022 (Predecessor), a decrease of $11.5 million, or 1.8%, compared to $623.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2021 (Predecessor). SG&A as a percent of sales decreased 1.9 percentage points to 12.1%, reflecting leverage on higher sales and lower stock compensation expense of $6.8 million due to a lower share price of Emerson’s stock during fiscal 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Net (loss) earnings attributable to Emerald JV
Subsubsection Title: Transaction and separation expenses
Subsubsection Text: Transaction and separation expenses were $43.8 million for the six months ended March 31, 2024 (Successor) and zero for the six months ended March 31, 2023 (Predecessor). Transaction and separation expenses in the Successor period included costs primarily associated with legal, IT, marketing, HR and finance advisory and consulting fees to support the Company’s separation and stand-up organization post-Acquisition.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Net (loss) earnings attributable to Emerald JV
Subsubsection Title: Amortization of intangibles
Subsubsection Text: Intangible amortization expense was $286.2 million for the six months ended March 31, 2024 (Successor) and $10.5 million for the six months ended March 31, 2023 (Predecessor). The increase year-over-year was primarily driven by the fair value step up of the Company’s acquired intangible assets and resulting increase in amortization basis following the Acquisition. Intangible amortization expense was $21.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2022 (Predecessor), a decrease of $1.9 million, or 8.2% compared to $23.0 million for the year ended September 30, 2021 (Predecessor), primarily due to various immaterial changes. -----

Subsubsection Text: Net sales were $1,676.9 million and $3,162.3 million for the four months ended September 30, 2023 (Successor) and eight months ended May 31, 2023 (Predecessor), respectively, and $5,060.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2022 (Predecessor). For the Combined year ended September 30, 2023, compared to the year ended September 30, 2022, net sales decreased 4.0%, reflecting a 7.0% decrease in volumes and a 1.0% unfavorable foreign currency impact, partially offset by a 3.0% increase in net pricing. By region, net sales were up 11.0% in Europe, down 7.0% in the Americas and down 15.0% in AMEA year-over-year. Volume declines were driven by softness in the U.S. residential market as well as in Singapore and the Middle East, partially offset by strength in Latin America and rebounds in China due to COVID-related shutdowns easing.

Subsection Title: Financial Position, Liquidity and Capital Resources
Subsubsection Text: Our primary sources of liquidity include our existing cash and cash equivalents, cash flows from operations and availability under our Revolving Credit Facility. Our primary uses of liquidity are operating expenses, funding of our debt requirements, separation-related activities, and capital expenditures. We believe that our available cash and cash equivalents, cash flows from operations, and availability under our Revolving Credit Facility will be sufficient to meet our liquidity needs, including principal and interest payments on debt obligations, capital expenditures, anticipated working capital requirements, and operating requirements, including those related to salaries, wages, and other liquidity requirements associated with operations for the foreseeable future. The Company also has certain contractual obligations primarily related to operating leases. We believe our liquidity position at March 31, 2024 remains strong and we will continue to closely monitor and proactively manage our liquidity as economic conditions change.

Subsubsection Title: Borrowings Post Financing Transactions
Subsubsection Text: As of March 31, 2024, after giving effect to the Transactions as well as the extinguishment of the Original Term Loan B Facility and the issuance of the Refinanced Term Loan B Facility, we have approximately $5,438.7 million in total third-party indebtedness outstanding, none of which is subordinated and all of which is senior secured indebtedness, consisting of $1,965.5 million of borrowings under the Term Loan Facilities, and $3,523.2 million (equivalent) of the Initial Notes, net of $49.9 million in unamortized discount, premium, and debt issuance costs. In addition, as of March 31, 2024, we have approximately $399.5 million of availability to incur additional secured indebtedness under the Revolving Credit Facility, subject to borrowing base capacity (after giving effect to approximately $9.1 million of letters of credit expected to be outstanding before giving effect to the financing costs). Further, the Company has outstanding indebtedness to related parties comprised of the Seller Notes, amounting to approximately $2,344.9 million as of March 31, 2024, inclusive of paid-in-kind interest, which is structurally subordinated to any debt owed to third parties. As market conditions warrant, we and our equityholders, including Blackstone, Emerson, and their affiliates and members of management, may from time to time, depending upon market conditions, seek to repurchase debt securities that we have issued or repay borrowings under our credit facilities, including the Initial Notes and borrowings under our Senior Secured Credit Facilities, in privately negotiated or open market transactions, by tender offer or otherwise, and such repurchases may be at prices below par and such repurchases may be for a material amount of the relevant debt securities or loans.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Business Combination
Subsubsection Text: The Company accounts for business combinations under the acquisition method of accounting. This method requires the recording of acquired assets, including separately identifiable intangible assets, at their acquisition date fair values. Any excess of the purchase price over the estimated fair value of the identifiable net assets acquired is recorded as goodwill. The determination of the estimated fair value of assets acquired requires management’s judgment and often involves the use of significant estimates and assumptions, including assumptions with respect to the weighted average cost of capital, discount rate, prospective financial information including revenue growth rate, EBITDA margin, customer attrition rates, royalty rates, obsolescence factors, asset lives and market multiples, among other items. When necessary, the Company consults with external advisors to help determine fair value. For non-observable market values, the Company may determine fair value using acceptable ----- valuation principles, including the excess earnings, relief from royalty, lost profit or cost methods. Management’s estimates of fair value are based upon assumptions believed to be reasonable, but which are inherently uncertain and unpredictable, and as a result, actual results may differ from estimates. In addition, unanticipated events and circumstances may occur that may affect the accuracy or validity of such estimates. During the measurement period, which is one year from the acquisition date, the Company may record adjustments to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed with the corresponding offset to goodwill. Upon conclusion of the measurement period, any subsequent adjustments are recorded to earnings.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Revenue Recognition
Subsubsection Text: In accordance with Accounting Standards Codification (ASC) 606, Revenue from Contracts with _Customers, the Company evaluates its contracts with customers to identify the promised goods or services and_ recognize revenue for the identified performance obligations at the amount the Company expects to be entitled to in exchange for those goods or services. A performance obligation is a promise in a contract to transfer a distinct good or service to a customer. Revenue is recognized when, or as performance obligations are satisfied, and control has transferred to the customer, typically when products are shipped or delivered, title and risk of loss pass to the customer, and the Company has a present right to payment. The vast majority of the Company’s revenues are performance obligations related to the sale of manufactured products which are recognized at a point in time when control transfers in accordance with shipping terms. In limited circumstances, contracts include multiple performance obligations, where revenue is recognized separately for each good or service, as well as contracts where revenue is recognized over time as control transfers to the customer. For revenues recognized over time, the Company typically uses an input method to determine progress and recognize revenue, based on costs incurred. The Company believes costs incurred closely correspond with its performance under the contract and the transfer of control to the customer. In sales arrangements that involve multiple performance obligations, revenue is allocated based on the relative standalone selling price for each performance obligation. Observable selling prices from actual transactions are used whenever possible. In other instances, the Company determines the standalone selling price based on thirdparty pricing or management’s best estimate. Payment terms vary but are generally short-term in nature. The Company’s long-term contracts, where revenue is generally recognized over time, are billed as work progresses in accordance with the contract terms and conditions, either at periodic intervals or upon achievement of certain milestones. The timing of revenue recognition and billings under these contracts results in either unbilled receivables (contract assets) when revenue recognized exceeds billings, or customer advances (contract liabilities) when billings exceed revenue recognized. Unbilled receivables are reclassified to accounts receivable when an unconditional right to consideration exists, typically when a milestone in the contract is achieved. The Company does not evaluate whether the transaction price includes a significant financing component for contracts where the time between cash collection and performance is less than one year. Certain arrangements with customers include variable consideration, typically in the form of rebates, cash discounts or penalties. Other than standard product warranty provisions, sales arrangements provide no other post shipment obligations on the Company. In most instances, returns are limited to product quality issues. The Company records a reduction to revenue at the time of sale to reflect the ultimate amount of consideration it expects to receive. The Company’s estimates are updated quarterly based on historical experience, trend analysis, and expected market conditions. Variable consideration is typically not constrained at the time revenue is recognized. The Company records amounts billed to customers for the costs of shipping and handling in sales transactions as Revenue and such costs are not considered separate performance obligations. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Goodwill and Other Intangibles Impairment Testing
Subsubsection Text: The Company amortizes definite-lived intangible assets on a straight-line basis over their useful lives. Goodwill is not amortized and is required to be assessed at least annually for impairment, or more frequently if triggering events indicate a possible impairment. The Company continually evaluates financial performance, economic conditions and other recent developments in assessing if a triggering event indicates that the carrying value of goodwill is impaired. Goodwill is tested for impairment at the reporting unit level by first performing a qualitative assessment to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is less than its carrying value. If the reporting unit does not pass the qualitative assessment, then a quantitative assessment is performed to compare the reporting unit’s carrying value to its fair value. Estimated fair values are developed primarily under an income approach that discounts estimated future cash flows using risk adjusted interest rates, as well as earnings multiples or other techniques as warranted. Fair values are subject to changes in underlying economic conditions. Alternatively, we are permitted to bypass the qualitative assessment and proceed directly to performing the quantitative assessment. Goodwill is considered impaired if the carrying value of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value. The fair value of the reporting unit is based on a discounted cash flow model involving several assumptions. Identifiable intangible assets consist of intellectual property, trade names, developed technology, backlog, and customer relationships and are also subject to evaluation for potential impairment if events or circumstances indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable. No goodwill or intangible asset impairment was recorded for any of the periods presented.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Stock-based Compensation
Subsubsection Text: The Company measures equity-classified stock-based compensation awards at their grant date fair value, whereas liability-classified awards are remeasured to fair value at each reporting period. Expense for stock-based compensation awards is recognized over the requisite service period and forfeitures are accounted for as they occur.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Inventories
Subsubsection Text: Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or net realizable value and are valued based on standard costs which approximate average costs. Cost standards are revised at the beginning of each fiscal year. The annual effect of resetting standards plus operating variances incurred during each period are allocated between inventories and recognized in cost of sales as products are sold.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS

Subsubsection Text: Refer to Note 1 of the unaudited condensed and consolidated financial statements for the Successor period as well as Note 1 to the audited consolidated and combined financial statements for Predecessor period, under the caption “Summary of Significant Accounting Policies” included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Preparation of the Company’s financial statements requires management to make judgments, assumptions and estimates regarding uncertainties that could affect reported revenue, expenses, assets, liabilities and equity. The most significant areas where management judgments and estimates impact the financial statements are described below. Actual results in these areas could differ materially from management’s estimates under different assumptions or conditions. This discussion and analysis should be read in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements and related notes. For the Predecessor periods, the Company’s financial statements were prepared on a stand-alone basis derived from the consolidated financial statements and accounting records of Emerson. The financial statements for the Predecessor periods are presented as carve-out financial statements and reflect the combined historical results of operations, financial position and cash flows of Climate Technologies, as if such financial statements were historically managed this way, in conformity with GAAP.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Title: Foreign Currency Risk
Subsubsection Text: In the normal course of business, the Company is exposed to changes in foreign currency exchange rates and commodity prices. The Company’s foreign currency exposures relate to transactions denominated in currencies that differ from the functional currencies of its subsidiaries, principally Mexican pesos. Foreign exchange forwards are utilized, as needed, to hedge foreign currency exposures impacting sales or cost of sales transactions, firm commitments, or the fair value of assets and liabilities. Based on a hypothetical 10.0% weakening in the U.S. dollar across all currencies, the potential losses in future earnings, fair value or cash flows are not material. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Title: Commodities
Subsubsection Text: Commodity exposures are price fluctuations on forecasted purchases of copper and aluminum. All derivatives are associated with specific underlying exposures and the Company does not hold derivatives for trading or speculative purposes. The initial duration of hedge positions is less than two years. Based on a hypothetical 10% decrease in commodity prices or a 10.0% weakening in the U.S. dollar across all currencies, the potential losses in future earnings, fair value or cash flows are not material.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Title: Interest Rate Risk
Subsubsection Text: As of March 31, 2024, we have approximately $5,438.7 million of total third-party indebtedness outstanding, including $1,965.5 million of borrowings at variable interest rates under our Term Loan Facilities. A 0.25% increase in the rate of interest under our Term Loan Facilities would increase our annual interest expense by approximately $7.2 million. This amount would increase to the extent any additional variable interest rate borrowings are made on our Revolving Credit Facility. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading global manufacturer of mission critical compressors, controls, components and solutions to the HVACR market. We provide products that help enhance human health and comfort, protect food quality and safety, advance energy efficiency, and create environmentally sustainable infrastructure. Key components in an HVACR ecosystem include the compressor, controls, the condenser and the evaporator. We provide best-in-class compressors, controls, components and solutions for residential, commercial, industrial and transportation applications. We are the largest global manufacturer in our served markets with approximately 40% share in overall global compression, including approximately 70% in the North America residential HVAC segment, and strong positions within our non-compression offerings. Our large installed base of more than 150 million HVAC compressor units globally drives profitable aftermarket sales due to replacement dynamics, with approximately 80% of our net sales tied to repair or replacement activity. Ongoing technology leadership is a key driver of our ability to capitalize on the replacement cycle, as each successive generation of compressor provides greater cost savings, energy efficiency and higher levels of environmental sustainability impact. The replacement cycle is primarily driven by repair and replacement of HVACR systems. Our installed base provides a foundation for ongoing earnings resilience as systems age and require repair or replacement. Global regulations around the impact of refrigerants on global warming and the need for energy efficiency amplify replacement dynamics in our business. Globally, government programs and incentives support the adoption of new, more sustainable products creating a strong forward looking growth environment. Secular trends tied to human health and comfort, as well as food quality, safety and sustainability drive additional demand for our compression and solutions offerings. As the heart of an HVAC system, the compressor is the system’s most critical component, yet represents a small percentage of the unit cost to the consumer. For example, approximately three to five percent of the residential HVAC unit cost is associated with the compressor, but the compressor has a mission-critical impact on function and efficiency. Compressors enable the separation of the low-pressure side of an HVAC system, where heat is absorbed into the refrigerant, from the high-pressure side of the system, where heat is discharged from the refrigerant to a cooling medium (typically the ambient outside air). The compressor mechanically reduces the volume of low-side refrigerant, thereby increasing its pressure and enabling heated refrigerant to flow to the high-pressure side of the system, where it is cooled. ----- We offer a variety of compressor technologies to meet customer-specific applications. Compression technology is essential to improving system efficiency. In addition, refrigerant selection is dependent on rigorous testing by compressor manufacturers to evaluate for performance and reliability and approve for use. Globally, the HVACR system manufacturers are dependent upon compressor innovation to meet regulations for efficiency and more environmentally friendly refrigerants. Because compressors are highly engineered to meet our customers’ technical requirements, we work closely with them on ER&D efforts to develop technology that meets consumer needs and complies with regulatory changes. These tightly coupled relationships result from our industry leadership and help provide us with good forward-looking visibility to market needs and opportunities to differentiate ourselves.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Business Unit Overview
Subsubsection Text: Our business is organized into two broad categories (HVACR Technologies and Electronics and Controls), with three world areas included within the HVACR Technologies group (HVACR Americas, HVACR AMEA (Asia, Middle-East and Africa) and HVACR Europe).
