Further, for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024, we generated net sales and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA of $4,722.7 million and $1,361.0 million, respectively. See “Summary Historical Consolidated and Combined Financial Information” for a reconciliation of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA to net earnings, the closest comparable GAAP measure. ----- **NET SALES MIX[(1) ]** (1) As of the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: HVACR Technologies
Subsubsection Text: The businesses within our HVACR Technologies group are leading producers of compression and related controls and solutions for residential, commercial, refrigeration, industrial, and transport markets. Our pioneering leadership of the scroll type of compressor enables foundational leadership across a majority of our served markets. To meet the diverse needs of other compressor applications, we also provide hermetic, semi-hermetic, centrifugal, screw and reciprocating compressors. The depth and breadth of our portfolio is unmatched globally, allowing us to steward market change and innovation across a wide range of market segments and applications. Our global HVACR Technologies group generated 84% of our total net sales and 87% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We believe compressors lie at the nexus of energy efficiency, helping build environmental sustainability and playing a role in ESG-related trends. Environmental sustainability is inherently embedded in what we do, as we enable our customers to set environmental sustainability goals and consistently meet or exceed ever-increasing sustainability standards. The best compressors—the most energy efficient, the quietest, the most reliable—are also the most environmentally sustainable and the most cost efficient for our OEM customers and the end users of their products. Consistently improving energy efficiency and sustainability requires continued technological innovation which is made possible by our extensive and proven ER&D capabilities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: HVACR Americas is our largest business unit and operates within an environment where our scroll
Subsubsection Text: technology is extremely well-suited for applications across the served market. This business unit generated 57% of our total net sales and 59% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Our leading positions with the largest North American OEMs serving the residential, commercial and transportation segments is augmented by our leadership with a more fragmented set of refrigeration and industrial customers. Above and beyond the growth that an accelerated energy efficiency and low GWP refrigerant regulatory environment is driving for our core residential, commercial and refrigeration markets, our industrial business is well-positioned for sustainability-driven growth within the RNG segment. The industrial business is roughly divided 50/50 between traditional industrial refrigeration applications and RNG applications. The RNG space is growing at a double-digit compound annual growth rate the past few years and growth is expected to accelerate given sustainability trends and the associated policies and incentives to deal with landfill and other off-gassing, largely farm-digestor applications. We are well-positioned with key customers in this space, as well as with their solution providers and engineering contractors. Broad heating, cooling and refrigeration needs across the Americas region coupled with a mature regulatory environment provide a solid foundation for continued growth and innovation opportunities. Our leadership in HVACR AMEA is driven by balanced sales between residential, commercial and refrigeration applications. Our technology leadership in commercial, district and other heating and refrigeration segments in China is complemented by our broad leadership positions in the rest of the region, including high ambient temperature and residential applications in countries such as Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. HVACR AMEA generated 18% of our net sales and 22% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: HVACR Europe has historically been a strong commercial and refrigeration market and is now the fastest
Subsubsection Title: Electronics and Controls
Subsubsection Text: Our Electronics and Controls business unit is a global leader in cold chain controls, monitoring solutions and climate control products and solutions. We provide building and refrigeration controls and monitoring solutions for food retail and foodservice applications, refrigerated container and perishable cargo monitoring solutions for ----- cargo and marine applications and healthcare environmental safety monitoring solutions. Our business benefits from sustainability, energy management and digitalization tailwinds, including integrated refrigeration solutions across compressors and controls, market penetration opportunities with leading automation capabilities, expanding data services and analytics in cargo monitoring, and healthcare monitoring and grid-connected energy management solutions. We also provide traditional and connected thermostats, energy and building management solutions, gas valves, cooling controls and control electronics. Our business benefits from energy efficiency, connectivity and control tailwinds, including opportunities to support hospitality and multi-dwelling unit customers in achieving energy efficiency goals with smart thermostats and energy management software solutions. Our Electronics and Controls business unit generated 16% of our net sales and 13% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: HVACR Europe has historically been a strong commercial and refrigeration market and is now the fastest
Subsubsection Title: Product Offerings and Market Segments
Subsubsection Text: Within our two business units, we provide products and services across five key market segments, namely Commercial, Electronics and Control, Industrial, Refrigeration and Residential, throughout the Americas, AMEA and Europe. **NET SALES MIX[(1) ]** (1) As of the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Totals may exceed 100% due to rounding. Across the Copeland brand, as well as the Sensi, Verdant, Vilter and White-Rodgers sub-brands, we provide products that help enhance human health and comfort, protect food quality and safety, advance energy efficiency, and create environmentally sustainable infrastructure. ----- Comprising approximately 81% of our total net sales for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our HVACR market segments, including residential and commercial HVAC compression, refrigeration and related aftermarket, and industrial, play an important role for our business (approximately 36% residential HVAC compression, approximately 20% commercial HVAC compression, approximately 22% refrigeration and related aftermarket, and approximately 4% industrial). In addition, for the three months ended March 31, 2024, approximately 82% of our total net sales were generated from our HVACR compression market segment, consisting of approximately 34% residential HVAC compression (representing a 15% decrease in year over year sales), approximately 20% commercial HVAC compression (representing a 1% increase in year over year sales), approximately 23% refrigeration and related aftermarket (representing a 5% increase in year over year sales), and approximately 5% industrial (representing a 39% increase in year over year sales). The compressor is the most critical device within the HVACR system, and the most energy-intensive HVACR component. Each unit is engineered to meet application, segment, and customer requirements to efficiently separate the evaporator low-pressure side of the system from the condenser high-pressure side. There are six categories of compressor technology. We invented scroll technology and continue to innovate and scale this technology platform. Scroll’s flexibility in modulation, superior efficiency and advantages in performance best positions it to keep up with evolving industry technical requirements and to win share from other technology types. While scroll is the leading technology for a majority of our served HVACR applications, certain applications are better suited to other technologies. We have developed a full suite of technology options, including a new offering in oil-free centrifugal, to meet a wide range of customer technology needs. Our leading portfolio across operating parameters and served applications creates opportunities for us to leverage global ER&D efforts and to apply learnings from one segment or region to other segments or regions thus driving productivity and improving our ability to capture new opportunities in a timely fashion. In addition to our compression solutions, our Electronics and Controls market segment (to be distinguished from our Electronic and Controls business unit) generated approximately 19% of our total net sales for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024 and approximately 18% for the last three months ended March 31, 2024 (representing a 10% decrease in year over year sales). Our portfolio of “control” products includes perishable and environmental monitoring solutions, control systems, thermostats, food safety instruments and software solutions. These products support climate and energy management in residential and commercial buildings, as well as across the cold chain.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: HVACR Europe has historically been a strong commercial and refrigeration market and is now the fastest
Subsubsection Title: Customers and Distribution Channels
Subsubsection Text: Our customers include the world’s largest HVAC system OEMs and regional and local HVAC providers, as well as distributors, wholesalers and end users. Through our market and technology leadership and global production capacity, we have achieved significant share with leading OEMs who represent approximately one-third of global sales. Our approximately 800 other customers account for the other two-thirds of global sales. These longtenured OEM relationships provide long-term volume stability, scale and influence. Our highly diversified customer base helps minimize risks associated with customer concentration. We tailor our go-to-market strategy across the value chain to best suit specific segments and end customers. Approximately two-thirds of our products are sold directly to OEMs globally. OEM customers seek advantages in efficiency, applied cost and compressor performance to reduce design complexity and improve performance. We also sell our products directly to secondary buyers such as distributors and contractors. Our strong reputation for product quality and durability, which reduce warranty costs for OEMs and the total long-term cost of ownership for end customers, has pull-through effects on OEMs and the entire value chain. We further collaborate with channel influencers, such as researchers, regulators, technical schools and utility providers, to create connectivity with the entire HVACR ecosystem. In the food retail and food service industries, we work directly with end users as well as the OEMs to provide solutions, which are sold either to the OEM, through intermediaries or directly to the end user. We and our customers invest significant time and resources in designing products to meet required specifications for each application and technology platform. As a result, we are highly integrated with our customers, augmenting our strong market position. OEMs launch new product platforms every seven to ten years, typically in connection with new regulatory standards. These new platforms require significant redesigns that need ----- many years of product development and close alignment between the OEM and its compressor suppliers. This dynamic inherently favors our company due to the long-standing, close working relationships between our engineering teams and our key OEM customers. Between formal launches, platforms are continually modified to reduce cost and improve efficiency and reliability. The redesign process is less significant and favors the original compressor supplier on the OEM platform. In addition to our integration in the development cycle, we have built channels and technical support structures with OEM partners, where they rely on us to provide aftermarket support and continue to service the installed base. Our role as a trusted partner in customer design and manufacturing processes has resulted in low customer turnover. Our technological advantage, deeply integrated partnerships with OEM customers and strong quality performance together make us indispensable to our customers and support our ability to maintain margins despite rising input costs. LTAs include mechanisms to pass through material cost inflation in order to provide stability and resiliency. On average, LTAs are three to four years in length and approximately one-third of our total net sales are covered by LTAs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: HVACR Europe has historically been a strong commercial and refrigeration market and is now the fastest
Subsubsection Title: Technology Leadership
Subsubsection Text: The ongoing cycle of periodic new platform launches and subsequent updates provides us with line of sight into future customer technology needs, enabling us to tailor our ER&D efforts around anticipated customer demands. In doing so, we help OEMs keep pace with and shape technology innovations in the HVACR industry. We have developed a robust and repeatable ER&D process to enable us to be a consistent innovation pioneer. Key capabilities include: technology discovery and maturation; front-end innovation; world class laboratories and ecosystems; specialized technical expertise; partnerships with universities, national labs and government agencies; regulatory agency and industry leadership; and new product development support. With more than 1,400 engineering and ER&D employees and approximately 500,000 square feet of engineering labs at 12 major ER&D centers worldwide, including three in Asia and five in Europe, we have substantial infrastructure to build on our technology leadership. Our ER&D strategy is further supported by the development of the Helix, an industry-first space where stakeholders can innovate at a system or ecosystem level around the industry’s biggest, most complex challenges. The Helix includes six simulated real-world, fully functional environments allowing us to test and demonstrate our integrated solutions in real-world environments. The Helix positions our company as a key thought leader and solutions provider in the HVACR industry.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: HVACR Europe has historically been a strong commercial and refrigeration market and is now the fastest
Subsubsection Title: Geographic and Manufacturing Footprint
Subsubsection Text: We serve our customers through 27 global manufacturing facilities and 12 major global ER&D centers, with a global headcount of approximately 18,000 employees. Global scale paired with localized manufacturing enable us to think globally and act locally, creating a flexible and robust supply chain that is regionalized to provide customers with a strong on-time delivery record. This advantage is derived not just from global operations, but also from the breadth of our product offerings and our ability to meet customers’ requirements. Decades of research and customer collaboration have ultimately yielded an unmatched global HVAC installed base of more than 150 million units. Our HVACR business is geographically focused in the Americas, where we generate approximately 70% of total net sales, with AMEA and Europe generating approximately 20% and 11% of total net sales, respectively. As the European business continues to grow at a pace faster than other regions due to heat pump and other application opportunities, we will benefit from further diversification and greater global presence. Traditional European compressor manufacturers do not have meaningful presence in residential applications, thus favoring our competitive position as we help build out a heat pump infrastructure to replace fossil-fuel burning boiler systems. Our continued global expansion into new regions with attractive market dynamics remains a priority and will be actively supported by our existing global infrastructure and network. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: HVACR Europe has historically been a strong commercial and refrigeration market and is now the fastest
Subsubsection Text: growing business unit as fossil-fueled boiler systems are being replaced by heat pump and dual fuel solutions, applications where we are a leading compressor and solutions provider. HVACR Europe generated 9% of our net sales and 6% of our Adjusted EBITDA for the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We participate in the HVACR compression and related solutions and controls markets with a focus on residential, commercial, refrigeration, transportation, industrial and cold chain applications. We estimate that the total annual sales in the market segments addressable by our current product offerings is approximately $13.4 billion and such market is expected to grow at a compound annual rate of approximately 4% over the next five years. Demand in our markets is supported by attractive macro drivers such as global regulation shifts, industrydriven sustainability goals and regulatory subsidies and incentives. Based on our current market positioning, our global scale and flexibility of our supply chain, and our manufacturing and ER&D capabilities, we are wellpositioned to capitalize on these trends. - **Regulatory Changes: Regulatory changes have driven change and innovation in our industry for decades. However, the frequency and impact of those changes has increased in recent years. These changes include updates to SEER requirements (and other global efficiency standards) and new standards on refrigerants that drive more frequent compressor and system innovations. The complexity resulting from these changes favors our global breadth and the depth of our engineering, technology and operations. In the United States, new efficiency regulations went into effect January 1, 2023. In 2025, new refrigerant regulations will again drive new compressors and systems into the market. Additional new regulations in the next seven to ten years are anticipated. Engineering and development efforts typically begin years in advance of the applicable regulation effective date. Our OEM customers depend on us to help them meet these requirements in a timely fashion while simultaneously helping them innovate and differentiate to meet their sustainability goals. Europe’s sustainability goals and their desire for energy sovereignty is driving goals and incentives targeting the installation of 30 million new heat pumps by 2030. - **Heat Pump Conversion: The growth of heat pumps is expected to bring new customers into the HVAC market, as households convert a furnace-only or gas-only system to a heat pump. According to a major consulting practice, consumers enjoy on average approximately $4,000 in lifetime savings ----- from heat pumps, supported by government subsidy programs and incentives available from utility providers. - Conversion to heat pumps is expected to be particularly strong in Europe, where high natural gas prices are incentivizing a transition to less energy-intensive heat pumps. The EU is in the process of revising its EPBD to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 55% by 2030, a legal obligation under the European climate law, and make the EU climate-neutral by 2050. While the revision is still under negotiation, the EPBD is expected to require member states to ensure that all new buildings after 2027 are zero-emission, and set deadlines after which the use of fossil fuel heating systems in new buildings, or in major building renovations or renovations of the heating systems, will not be permitted. Existing regulations across nine European countries have already implemented, or will implement by 2026, fossil fuel boiler bans in residential buildings. With the upcoming revision of the EPBD, we expect that all other EU member states will implement similar restrictions and the scope will ultimately comprise all existing buildings. Some countries also already provide, or are expected to provide, monetary incentives to accelerate the transition to clean heating, including heat pumps. With strong channel benefits and an existing customer base, the major legacy boilermakers are playing a critical role in the heat pump transition. Our HVAC compression expertise positions us as an important partner as legacy boilermakers help drive heat pump adoption. Our partnership and existing share with legacy boilermakers and HVAC OEMs positions us well to enable this transition. We are currently a leader in compression for the heat pump segment in Europe. - **COVID-19 / Hybrid Working: More waking hours spent at home are expected to maintain HVAC usage above pre-COVID-19 levels, shortening system useful life. According to a major consulting practice, these new working arrangements are expected to keep replacement rates elevated as approximately 45% of employees are predicted to be in hybrid working models in the future versus approximately 10% pre-COVID-19. HVACR industry executives also expect replacement rates to remain elevated. Run times in 2020 were quoted as being 30% higher than 2019 levels (after adjusting for weather), which should correlate to higher rates of replacement over time. - **Environmental and Population Shifts: With environmental change resulting in more extreme temperatures across the United States, and a population mix increasingly shifting to warmer southern states, HVAC usage has increased and is expected to continue to increase, resulting in shorter useful lives for HVAC equipment and higher replacement rates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Established global leader with clear #1 market position
Subsubsection Text: We are the #1 manufacturer of HVACR compression products in the segments and regions where we compete, driven by technology leadership, strong brand recognition, global facilities footprint and long-term customer relationships. We are the clear leader in terms of global scale and presence, as well as breadth and quality of our product portfolio, and we compete against different peers in each segment and region where we operate. Our size and scale enable operational synergies driven by our ability to leverage technology, ER&D and manufacturing excellence across regions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Unrivaled breadth and depth of product portfolio and capabilities executed through a global ER&D supply network, and well-positioned for innovation
Subsubsection Text: Our global manufacturing capabilities, paired with our leading portfolio of SKUs and patents, enable us to provide what our customers need, where they need it, and when they need it. No competitor can match our global reach across markets and segments. Our leading technology position is supported by more than 3,000 patents and pending applications. Extensive ER&D capabilities in the United States and Asia, along with a growing ER&D functionality in Europe, enable us to offer truly global ER&D capabilities to meet the needs of each individual customer and application. ----- These capabilities, combined with our deeply integrated relationships with leading OEMs and decades of experience have made us an industry leader in technological advancement. We work collaboratively with regulators to understand future efficiency capability standards and we are developing the solutions to meet those standards with the world’s leading HVACR manufacturers. Leveraging these partnerships and our global ER&D infrastructure, we are able to take a leadership position in shaping each wave of regulatory transition. Our deep appreciation of the end user helps us tailor our technology to each customer’s needs, bringing our global expertise to provide local solutions. This continued technological leadership has helped make us the most trusted name in compressor solutions. Given our manufacturing presence and ER&D capabilities, we are wellpositioned for the industry’s transition to heat pumps. Planned and anticipated regulatory changes governing efficiency and refrigerants are expected to provide stable, ongoing tailwinds to both price and volume. New regulations from the U.S. Department of Energy went into effect in 2023, with energy efficiency requirements varied by region, and OEM partners are relying on us to design products that comply with the new regulations. The anticipated transition to low-GWP refrigerants in 2025 will require considerable engineering, given that compliant refrigerants exhibit different characteristics from existing refrigerants, such as operating pressures and flammability.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Mission critical partner to a diversified global customer base characterized by long-term relationships
Subsubsection Text: As the heart of an HVAC system, the compressor is the system’s most critical component, yet represents a small percentage of the unit cost to the consumer. For example, approximately three to five percent of the residential HVAC unit cost is associated with the compressor, but the product has a mission-critical impact on function and efficiency. Compression innovation can create performance, reliability and cost advantages to system design, therefore enabling value-based selling. Customers will pay a premium for compressors that achieve superior levels of efficiency, enabling them to reduce other costs within the system design and resulting in an overall lower total applied system cost. We and our customers invest significant time and resources in designing products to meet specifications required by each application and technology platform. As a result, we are highly integrated with our customers, augmenting our industry leadership and helping provide us with good forward-looking visibility to market needs and opportunities to differentiate. LTAs further support revenue visibility and customer retention. Outside of the United States, where the customer base is more diversified and fragmented, LTAs are utilized less frequently.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Highly engineered offering promotes customer retention through customer process integration
Subsubsection Text: In addition to the critical nature of compressors within HVAC systems, we also serve as a critical engineering, development, and manufacturing partner to our customers. We provide crucial services to our customers at every stage of the product lifecycle by: - Helping customers develop specifications to meet new regulatory requirements - Innovating compressor technology to meet the requirements - Manufacturing units at scale and on time to support new platform launches - Developing updates to existing platforms in partnership with customers - Providing aftermarket products and services to help end-users realize the full useful lives of their HVACR systems Deep interconnectivity with our customers’ design and manufacturing processes helps us to provide bestin-class service and support to our customers. This deep integration incentivizes our customers to maintain their relationships with us. Customer turnover is less than one percent historically. Our technical expertise and operational support make us a trusted partner. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Resilient business model supported by established installed base and high replacement volumes
Subsubsection Text: Replacement as a percent of sales has increased to more than 85% over the last 50 years in the North America residential HVAC industry, with a current installed base of approximately 100 million units. Replacement sales are more resilient and are associated with durable spend, often outperforming GDP growth rates during economic cycles. Both HVACR systems broadly and compressors specifically suffer from wear. Compressors may be replaced to extend the life of an HVACR system. Full system replacement occurs when HVACR units are beyond repair or when an end-user determines that the payback in higher efficiency, lower emissions and better reliability is sufficient to warrant the cost of replacement. Repair or replacement of a unit is non-discretionary because HVACR systems provide essential heating, cooling and refrigeration. Our resilient recovery during the 2007-2008 Global Financial Crisis speaks to the largely non-discretionary nature of HVAC repair and replacement. Despite an approximately 15% revenue contraction in 2009, our revenues rebounded quickly in 2010 with more than 19% growth before returning to normalized long-term growth rates. Over the same period, we delivered improvements in gross margin and EBITDA margin as we moved quickly to manage costs. Our cost structure is largely variable, enabling us to preserve margin during downturns such as the 2007-2008 Global Financial Crisis, the U.S. manufacturing downturn, and the COVID-19 pandemic. Secular industry tailwinds, including upcoming regulatory changes, heat pump conversion, shifts in population and the impact of hybrid working, are expected to drive an increase in HVAC usage. This increase in usage can create more wear on HVAC systems and shorten systems’ useful lives, resulting in increased repair and replacement rates and driving further demand for replacement products supporting our long-term resilient growth.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Proven leadership team with an unmatched breadth of experience
Subsubsection Text: Our business is led by a highly qualified and experienced management team. Our management consistently delivered value to stakeholders while operating as a standalone segment of Emerson. In partnership with Blackstone, the Copeland team continues to drive innovation and execute on operational excellence in order to capitalize on strong industry tailwinds.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Strong financial profile with best-in-class profitability and free cash flow generation, poised for margin expansion through identified efficiency opportunities
Subsubsection Text: We have delivered robust and consistent through-the-cycle cash flow performance and top-line growth, supported by secular industry tailwinds, technology leadership, embedded relationships with customers, and the mission-critical nature of our product offerings. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We operate in highly competitive markets. We compete based on product performance, quality, delivery, branding, service, total applied cost and/or price across the industries and markets served. A significant element of our competitive strategy is to deliver solutions to our customers by manufacturing high-quality products at the best applied cost. Although no single company competes directly with us in all of our product lines, various companies compete in one or more product lines with the number of competitors varying by product line. Some competitors have substantially greater sales, assets and financial resources than our business and we also compete with many smaller companies. We believe we have a market leadership position in many of our product lines.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We maintain an intellectual property portfolio we have developed or acquired over a number of years, including patents, trademarks and licenses. We also continue to develop or acquire new intellectual property. New patent applications are continuously filed to protect our ongoing research and development activities and we periodically review the continued utility of patent assets. Our trademark registrations may be renewed and their duration is dependent upon national laws and trademark use. While this proprietary intellectual property portfolio is important to our business in the aggregate, we do not regard our business as being dependent on any single patent, trademark registration or license. We believe that we have taken all necessary steps to protect our intellectual property rights, but no assurance can be given that we will be able to successfully enforce or protect our rights in the event that they are infringed upon by a third-party.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to a number of U.S. federal and state and foreign laws and regulations that affect manufacturing companies. Many of these laws and regulations are still evolving and being tested in courts. These involve HVACR efficiency and refrigeration requirements, the environment, labor and employment, health and safety, intellectual property, data privacy and security, advertising, marketing, competition, consumer protection, taxation, economic or other trade prohibitions or sanctions and securities law compliance. _Environmental Regulation_ Our operations, products and services are subject to various environmental laws and regulations, including obligations to obtain and comply with permits required for the operation of our business and to meet applicable safety or stewardship standards. Our manufacturing locations generate wastes (including hazardous wastes), of which use, handling, storage, treatment, transportation, discharge and disposal are subject to U.S. federal, state, foreign and/or local laws and regulations relating to pollution, public and worker health and safety and protection of the environment. We strive to minimize the environmental impact of our operations through pollution control technologies, facility design and operating procedures. Compliance with environmental laws and regulations has not had, and based on currently available information and the applicable laws and regulations currently in effect, is not expected to have a material effect on our capital expenditures (including expenditures for pollution control equipment), earnings or competitive position. However, environmental requirements have and are expected to continue to become increasingly stringent, and environmental laws and regulations may be changed, accelerated or adopted that impose significant operational restrictions and compliance requirements upon us and which could negatively impact our operating results. In addition, we are also subject to obligations under federal and state environmental laws to complete investigations and remediation at several of our current and former operating locations as well as having been assessed a share of responsibility for remedial activities at certain third-party disposal (i.e., “Superfund”) sites. Based on our information regarding the nature and volume of wastes allegedly disposed of or released at these properties, the total estimated cleanup costs and other financially viable potentially responsible parties, we do not believe the costs to us associated with these properties will be material, either individually or in the aggregate. As of ----- September 30, 2023, financial reserves of $16.6 million have been established for the reasonably estimable costs of such matters. _Employee Health and Safety Regulations_ We are subject to requirements relating to safe working conditions and manufacturing practices, including in the United States federal and state Occupational Safety and Health (OSHA) standards and regulations. Employee health and safety in the workplace is one of our core values. The Climate Technologies leadership team will continue to support our employees with training, policies and other resources to provide a safe and healthy workplace. Hazards in the workplace are actively identified, and incident tracking is implemented, so that preventative and remedial actions can be taken to maintain and improve workplace safety.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are dedicated to modernizing our workplace culture with the goal of meeting the needs and expectations of today’s workers and attract talent that will help us thrive. We believe our success depends on our ability to attract, develop and retain key personnel. The skills, experience and industry knowledge of key employees significantly benefit our operations and performance. We develop our employees and future leaders internally with programs that focus on business development, managerial skills, inclusion and employee engagement. We support and develop our employees through global training and development programs that build and strengthen employees’ leadership and professional skills. Leadership development programs include intensive learning programs for new leaders as well as more established leaders. We also partner with educational institutions and nonprofit organizations to help prepare current and future workers with knowledge and skills to succeed. To assess and improve employee retention and engagement, we survey employees with the assistance of third-party consultants, and take actions to address areas of employee concern. We have identified other human capital priorities, including, among other things, providing competitive wages and benefits and promoting an inclusive work environment. We are focused on efforts to elevate the representation of women and U.S. minorities and foster an inclusive work environment that supports our large global workforce and helps us innovate for our customers. Employee resource groups have been created to support our diverse workforce. We also have taken actions with the goal of enhancing diversity, including setting diversity targets for interview slates and recruiting at venues representing women, minorities, U.S. military veterans, and LGBTQ+ talent. Employee levels are managed to align with the pace of our business and management believes it has sufficient human capital to operate its business successfully. We have approximately 17,800 employees located around the world. Management believes that our employee relations are favorable. A small portion of our U.S. employees are unionized, and outside the U.S., we have employees in certain countries, particularly in Europe, that are represented by an employee representative organization, such as a union, works council or employee association.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to various litigations, claims and other proceedings that arise from time to time in the ordinary course of business. We believe these actions are routine and incidental to the business. While the outcome of these actions cannot be predicted with certainty, we do not believe that any will have a material adverse impact on our business. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Set forth below is certain information regarding our executive officers, including their ages as of March 31, 2024. Since the closing of the Acquisition, we have built-out a new executive leadership team. We are currently undertaking an external search for a new Chief Financial Officer and expect to appoint a new hire substantially concurrently with or shortly following the closing of this offering. Until such new CFO is hired, the office of the CFO will continue to be led by Vice President, Global Controller David Will and Senior Vice President Finance Gregory Harre, who each report directly to Ross Shuster, Chief Executive Officer. JV NewCo, the indirect parent company of the Issuer that oversees the management of our business, is governed by the JV NewCo GP Board, which is controlled by BCP Emerald and currently consists of three managers appointed by BCP Emerald, two managers appointed by Emerson and the CEO of JV NewCo (a nonvoting member), and three independent managers. For a more detailed description of the JV NewCo GP Board, see “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—JV NewCo Governance Documents—Board Rights.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Ross B. Shuster .......................................... 58 Chief Executive Officer Darel Calis .................................................. 57 Chief Operating Officer Patrick Forsythe ......................................... 56 Chief Technology Officer Stuart Dalgleish .......................................... 54 Chief Human Resources Officer Fiona Cleland ............................................. 48 Senior Vice President, Strategy, Mergers & Acquisitions Gregory Harre ............................................ 48 Senior Vice President, Finance David Will .................................................. 40 Vice President, Global Controller Tracy Reiter ................................................ 42 Chief Transformation and Sustainability Officer Christine Carney......................................... 40 Chief Legal Officer and Secretary John Schneider ........................................... 55 President, HVACR Americas Sandeep Nair .............................................. 56 President, HVACR AMEA Sandro Matic .............................................. 37 President, HVACR Europe Craig Rossman ........................................... 51 President, Electronics and Controls _Ross B. Shuster currently serves as our President and Chief Executive Officer, a position he has held since_ 2023. Mr. Shuster served as the Chief Executive Officer of Howden upon it becoming a private company in September, 2019 until its acquisition by Chart Industries, Inc. in March 2023. Mr. Shuster has vast global business experience having held a variety of executive leadership roles with responsibility for international and global businesses within companies including United Technologies and Johnson Controls. Mr. Shuster received a B.S. in Mechanical Engineering from the University of California, Davis and an MBA from the University of San Francisco. _Darel Calis currently serves as our Chief Operating Officer, a position he has held since June 2024. Mr._ Calis most recently served as Segment Vice President of Global Operations at TE Connectivity, and held similar roles in operations at Sequa Automotive Group as Vice President of Global Operations and at Federal-Mogul Corporation, where he held various operational leadership roles. Mr. Calis received a B.S. in Industrial Technology and Project Management from Wentworth Institute of Technology and an MBA from the University of Tennessee. _Patrick Forsythe currently serves as our Chief Technology officer, a position he has held since 2024._ Mr. Forsythe most recently served as the Chief Technology Officer at Generac Power Systems. Prior to his role at Generac, he held similar senior positions at Hayward, Doosan and Ingersoll Rand. Mr. Forsythe received a Management Engineering degree and an M.S. in Manufacturing and Technology from The Open University. _Stuart Dalgleish currently serves as our Chief Human Resources Officer, a position he has held since 2023._ Mr. Dalgleish served as the Chief Human Resources Officer at Howden from 2020 to 2023, a leading global air and gas handling engineering business which was owned by KPS partners up until being acquired by Chart Industries in ----- March 2023. Mr. Dalgleish was also Chief People Officer from September 2016 to February 2020 at Hive, one of Europe’s leading smart home providers. He previously held a variety of roles in human resources and business leadership in Centrica, Talisman Energy, ConocoPhillips and National Air Traffic Services throughout the U.K. and in China, the U.S. and Canada. Mr. Dalgleish received a B.A. in Business Studies from Napier University, Edinburgh and is a Chartered Fellow of the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development. _Fiona Cleland currently serves as Senior Vice President of Strategy, Mergers & Acquisition, a position she_ has held since 2024. Ms. Cleland most recently served as Senior Vice President of Strategy and Corporate Development at ATS Corporation. She previously held a variety of strategy and acquisition roles at Honeywell International and Danaher. Ms. Cleland received an Electronic Engineering degree from Newcastle University and a Business Administration degree from Copenhagen Business School. _Gregory Harre currently serves as Senior Vice President of Finance, a position he has held since 2023 and_ as one of our interim co-leads of the office of the Chief Financial Officer, a position he has held since 2024. Prior to that, Mr. Harre was Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Emerson’s Commercial & Residential Solutions business, a position he held since 2021. Mr. Harre first joined Emerson in 1997 with roles of increasing responsibility, including Vice President & Chief Financial Officer of the Climate Technologies Asia Middle East & Africa business, Vice President of Finance for Automation Solutions, Controller for Tool Company, and various finance roles in the Emerson Corporate Headquarters. Mr. Harre received a B.S. from Southern Illinois University in Accountancy and an M.B.A. from the Olin School of Business at Washington University in St. Louis. _David Will currently serves as our VP, Global Controller, a position he has held since September 2023 and_ as one of our interim co-leads of the office of the Chief Financial Officer, a position he has held since 2024. Prior to that, Mr. Will was Vice President, Chief Accounting Officer at Quaker Houghton where he led the global controllership organization. He also spent time with Trinseo and contributed to its initial public offering in June 2014. Mr. Will began his career at PricewaterhouseCoopers and is a licensed CPA. Mr. Will received a B.S. in Accounting from Washington and Lee University and an M.B.A. from Villanova University. _Tracy Reiter currently serves as our Chief Transformation and Sustainability Officer, a position she has_ held since 2023. Mrs. Reiter first joined Emerson in 2011 and has held a number of roles with various Emerson businesses, including Vice President Information Technology, Vice President & CIO and Vice President Business Development, Strategic Planning, and Marketing. Prior to joining Emerson, Mrs. Reiter held account leadership roles at Ernst & Young and Gartner. Mrs. Reiter received a B.B.A in Management Information Systems and Business Administration from the University of Tulsa, as well as an M.B.A from the Olin School of Business at Washington University in St. Louis. _Christine Carney currently serves as our Chief Legal Officer and Secretary, a position she has held since_ 2023. Ms. Carney first joined Emerson in 2007 and subsequently held roles of increasing responsibility, including Senior Associate General Counsel of Emerson’s climate technologies business and Vice President & General Counsel – Americas. Ms. Carney received a B.S. in Business Administration and Economics, an M.B.A. and J.D. from Saint Louis University. _John Schneider currently serves as President of HVACR Americas, a position he has held since 2021._ Mr. Schneider first joined Emerson in 2000 as Market Manager, Residential Air Conditioning. Mr. Schneider subsequently held roles of increasing responsibility, including Vice President Marketing and Vice President Global Variable Speed. In 2013, Mr. Schneider was promoted to Vice President/General Manager Thermal Management, North America of Emerson’s Network Power business. In 2016, Emerson sold Network Power to Platinum Equity and Mr. Schneider went with the new company, Vertiv, where he was promoted to Senior Vice President, Global Thermal Management & Solutions. In 2020, Mr. Schneider rejoined Emerson as President of the Therm-O-Disc business. Mr. Schneider holds a B.S. in Chemical Engineering from The Ohio State University and an M.B.A. from Xavier University. _Sandeep Nair currently serves as the President of HVACR Asia, Middle East & Africa, a position he has_ held since 2020. Mr. Nair first joined Emerson in 1994 as a senior manager for Tata Liebert Ltd. in India. In 1996, Mr. Nair left Emerson and spent the next six years in leadership roles with Brother International and Acer Communications and Multimedia. Mr. Nair returned to Emerson in 2003, and has since served as President of ----- various businesses, including Thermo-Disc, Fusite and Emerson Network Power India. Mr. Nair received a B.S. and an M.B.A. from the University of Bombay. _Sandro Matic currently serves as the President of HVACR Europe, a position he has held since 2022._ Mr. Matic first joined Emerson in 2007, and has held a number of roles across the business, including Vice President Product Management & Operations, Vice President Operations & Supply Chain, Director of Sales in Eastern Europe, and various other positions. Mr. Matic received a B.A. from Rhein Main University of Applied Sciences, and an M.B.A. from IE Business School. _Craig Rossman currently serves as President of Electronics and Controls, a position he has held since_ 20237. Prior to this role, Mr. Rossman served as President of Comfort Controls, Director Investor Relations and Assistant Treasurer for Emerson. Mr. Rossman first joined Emerson in 1994, and has held numerous roles in both finance and general management, including Vice President Finance and General Manager, Temperature Sensors, within the Therm-O-Disc business, Vice President and Chief Financial Officer for Remote Automation Solutions and General Manager for Tekmar-Dohrmann. Mr. Rossman received a B.B.A. from the University of Cincinnati and an M.B.A. from Saint Louis University. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS JV NewCo Governance Documents
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the closing of the Acquisition (the “Closing”), (i) JV NewCo entered into an amended and restated limited partnership agreement (the “JV NewCo LPA”) with its general partner, Emerald GP Holdings G.P. LLC (“JV NewCo GP”), BCP Emerald and certain wholly owned holding company subsidiaries of Emerson, and (ii) JV NewCo GP entered into an amended and restated limited liability company agreement (the “JV NewCo GP LLCA” and, together with the JV NewCo LPA, the “Governance Documents”) with BCP Emerald and certain wholly owned holding company subsidiaries of Emerson. Capitalized terms used in this section and not defined herein have the meanings set forth in the JV NewCo LPA and the JV NewCo GP LLCA, as applicable. Upon the closing of the Unit Purchase Transaction, Emerson’s rights under the Governance Documents will terminate (other than in respect of certain indemnification and confidentiality obligations) and the Governance Documents will be amended and restated to reflect such termination of rights. Pursuant to the Governance Documents: _Board Rights. JV NewCo is governed by the board of managers of JV NewCo GP (the “JV NewCo GP_ Board”), which will be comprised of up to ten managers and currently consists of three managers appointed by BCP Emerald, two managers to be appointed by Emerson, the CEO of JV NewCo (who will be a non-voting manager), and three independent managers appointed by BCP Emerald in consultation with Emerson. Each of BCP Emerald and Emerson have the right to appoint up to three non-voting board observers. The rights of BCP Emerald and Emerson to appoint managers to the JV NewCo GP Board (and the number of votes each manager may cast) are subject to agreed step-downs in connection with transfers of their equity interests in JV NewCo (provided that each will have the right to appoint at least one manager if they own more than 10% of JV NewCo). Actions of the JV NewCo GP Board require consent of the managers holding a majority of the votes. The managers appointed by BCP Emerald hold a majority of the votes of the JV NewCo GP Board, and such votes are controlled by the BCP Emerald managers who are investment professionals of Blackstone. _Consent Rights. Each of BCP Emerald and Emerson have consent rights over certain fundamental matters_ including, without limitation, related party transactions, any acquisition or disposition of assets or stock with a purchase price in excess of $1 billion, and any incurrence of indebtedness that would exceed a certain specified pro forma leverage ratio. The consent rights are subject to certain fall-away provisions. _Transfer and Liquidity Rights._ Emerson will not be able to transfer any interest in JV NewCo, subject to certain exceptions, including transfers (i) to certain affiliates, (ii) in an IPO or a change of control sale, (iii) following an IPO (subject to certain restrictions discussed below), (iv) with the approval of the JV NewCo GP Board prior to the second anniversary of the Closing, (v) subject to BCP Emerald’s “tag-along” rights, in an amount not to exceed 50% and 100% of its interests in JV NewCo after the second and fifth anniversaries of the Closing, respectively (provided that Emerson may not sell its interests to a competitor or activist investor), or (vi) pursuant to the exercise of Emerson’s customary “tag-along” rights or in a change of control sale. Transfers by Emerson are generally subject to a “right of first offer” by BCP Emerald over the interests proposed to be transferred. BCP Emerald generally has the right to transfer any interest in JV NewCo, however, Emerson has customary “tag-along” rights (as mentioned above) unless such transfer is (i) pursuant to customary permitted transfer provisions, including to certain affiliates, (ii) in an IPO or a change of control sale, or (iii) in connection with a syndication of BCP Emerald’s equity within six months of closing, subject to certain parameters. BCP Emerald will also have the ability to force a change of control sale of JV NewCo; however, before the second anniversary of the Closing, any such sale must generate an agreed upon return. Emerson shall have the right to require JV NewCo to consummate a Qualified IPO after the fifth anniversary of the Closing and BCP Emerald shall have the right to require JV NewCo to consummate a Qualified IPO after the second anniversary of the Closing. Each of Emerson and BCP Emerald shall have the right to require ----- JV NewCo to consummate a Non-Qualified IPO after the seventh anniversary of the Closing. If Emerson makes a demand for JV NewCo to consummate an IPO (whether a Qualified IPO or a Non-Qualified IPO), BCP Emerald shall have a right of first offer to purchase all of the common equity that Emerson owns. Certain volume-related transfer restrictions will apply to Emerson in and following an IPO of JV NewCo, through a priority sell-down right granted to BCP Emerald, until BCP Emerald has received an agreed amount of sale proceeds. _Preemptive rights. Before an IPO, each party has preemptive rights with respect to any issuance of equity_ interests or debt securities in JV NewCo (subject to certain exceptions). _Non-Compete. Until 24 months after Emerson’s ownership interest in JV NewCo falls below 10%,_ Emerson will not, directly or indirectly, engage in, or have an interest in, manage, control or provide financing to, any business that competes with the Climate Technologies Business as conducted at the time of the Closing. Exceptions to this non-compete are (i) acquisitions of a diversified business having not more than 10% of its sales attributable to any competing business (or, if such sales exceed the 10% threshold, Emerson must divest below such threshold within 12 months of such acquisition) and (ii) ownership of less than 5% of the equity interests of any person engaged in a competing business. _Non-Solicit and Non-Hire. Until 24 months after Emerson’s ownership interest in JV NewCo falls below_ 10%, Emerson and JV NewCo may not solicit the following employees of the other: (i) executive or managerial employees; and (ii) employees engaged in the provision of services to the other under the Transition Services Agreement (discussed further below) in a senior, technical or managerial role, in each case of (i) and (ii), subject to certain customary exceptions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Acquisition, we created two new incentive plans for our employees’ performance and retention purposes, the Emerald JV Holdings L.P. 2023 Unit Incentive Plan and the Long-Term Incentive Plan. Certain members of management and other employees participate in such plans. We also have entered into new employment agreements with certain members of our management.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Acquisition, Emerson and JV NewCo entered into a Transition Services Agreement pursuant to which, following the Closing, each party provides the other party with various specified services on a transitional basis at pre-agreed costs, consisting of the services provided between Emerson and the Climate Technologies Business.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Closing, JV NewCo entered into a services agreement with Blackstone Management Partners L.L.C. and Blackstone Capital Partners VIII L.P. (collectively, “BX Management”). Under the services agreement, JV NewCo pays or reimburses BX Management and their affiliates for out-of-pocket costs and expenses incurred on behalf of or in connection with the monitoring and evaluation of the operations of JV NewCo. JV NewCo also indemnifies each of BX Management and certain of its related persons against, among other things, losses and liabilities incurred in connection with or as a result of the services provided to JV NewCo or its affiliates pursuant to the services agreement.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Closing, JV NewCo issued $2 billion aggregate initial liquidation preference of shares of Convertible PIK Preferred Equity to BCP Emerald. The Convertible PIK Preferred Equity rank senior in rights upon liquidation, dissolution or winding up of JV NewCo to common stock and any other class or series of equity securities of JV NewCo not specifically ranked senior to or pari passu with the Convertible PIK Preferred ----- Equity. The Convertible PIK Preferred Equity is structurally subordinate to the Seller Notes and the third-party debt financing. In lieu of dividends, the initial aggregate liquidation preference of the Convertible PIK Preferred Equity accretes daily, compounding semi-annually, at a rate equal to 7% per annum. The Convertible PIK Preferred Equity is non-voting, except that approval of the holders of a majority of the Convertible PIK Preferred Equity, voting as a separate class, is required for certain matters relating to the terms of the Convertible PIK Preferred Equity, the issuance of equity securities ranking senior to or pari passu with the Convertible PIK Preferred Equity, and certain reorganization transactions involving JV NewCo. The Convertible PIK Preferred Equity is mandatorily convertible upon a Qualified IPO (as defined in the JV NewCo GP LLCA) by JV NewCo or upon a Change of Control (as defined in the JV NewCo LPA) of JV NewCo. In an IPO, if the price per share of common stock sold in such IPO is greater than a 10% premium above the common equity purchase price at the Closing, the Convertible PIK Preferred Equity will automatically convert into common shares of the IPO Corporation. Otherwise, the Convertible PIK Preferred Equity will convert into a cash-pay preferred instrument (the “Cash-Pay Preferred Equity”) paying dividends at a 9% annual rate. The CashPay Preferred Equity remains convertible into common stock up to the accreted amount of the Convertible PIK Preferred Equity. If the Seller Notes remain outstanding after a Non-Qualified IPO, dividends on the Cash-Pay Preferred Equity compound at a 9% rate, but are not paid until the Seller Notes are repaid in full. BCP Emerald generally has the right to transfer the Convertible PIK Preferred Equity, however, Emerson will have customary “tag-along” rights in certain circumstances (as discussed above).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Closing, the Seller Notes Issuer issued two senior unsecured notes in aggregate principal amount of $2.25 billion to an affiliate of Emerson. Pursuant to the Note Purchase Agreement, the Seller Notes Issuer will repurchase the Seller Notes issued to EMR Holdings. For a description of the Seller Notes and the Seller Notes Repurchase, see “Description of Certain Other Indebtedness—Seller Notes” and “Summary—The Transactions—Seller Notes Repurchase.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Closing, that certain property located at 8000 and 8100 W. Florissant St. Louis, Missouri (the “Corporate Campus”) was transferred by Emerson to a subsidiary of Emerson, which was, in turn, transferred to a subsidiary of JV NewCo prior to the Closing. Beginning at the Closing, a portion of the Corporate Campus has been leased from such subsidiary of JV NewCo, as landlord, to Emerson, as tenant (the “Campus Lease”). The Campus Lease has a term of three years (subject to certain extension rights). The base rent payable under the Campus Lease is set at a rate per square foot of the Rentable Area (as defined in the Campus Lease). The tenant under the Campus Lease is obligated to pay as additional rent its proportionate share of all real estate taxes, insurance premiums, utility costs, repair and maintenance expenses and costs for ordinary capital improvements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Procedures with Respect to Review and Approval of Related Person Transactions
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, we may do business with certain companies affiliated with one or more members of the Investor Group or Emerson. The JV NewCo GP Board has not adopted a formal written policy for the review and approval of transactions with related persons. However, the JV NewCo GP Board expects to review and approve transactions with related persons as appropriate. In addition, a noted above, JV NewCo must obtain the consent of BCP Emerald and Emerson, as applicable, in connection with entry into certain related party transactions (subject to certain exceptions). -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The discussion and analysis presented in this Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations (the “MD&A”) includes the financial condition and results of operations specified in our unaudited condensed and consolidated balance sheet at March 31, 2024 (Successor), our audited condensed and consolidated balance sheet at September 30, 2023 (Successor), our consolidated and combined balance sheet at September 30, 2022 (Predecessor), our consolidated statements of operations, comprehensive (loss) income, equity and cash flows for the four months ended September 30, 2023 (Successor) and consolidated and combined statements of operations, comprehensive income (loss), equity and cash flows for the eight months ended May 31, 2023 (Predecessor) and the year ended September 30, 2022 (Predecessor), our consolidated statements of operations and comprehensive (loss) income for the six months ended March 31, 2024 (Successor), and our unaudited condensed, consolidated and combined statements of operations and comprehensive income (loss) for the six months ended March 31, 2023 (Predecessor) and the unaudited condensed, consolidated and combined statement of owners’ equity and statement of cash flows for the six months ended March 31, 2023 (Predecessor). Accordingly, the discussion and analysis of the historical predecessor periods prior to May 31, 2023 does not reflect the significant impact of the Transactions, as defined hereinafter, on our financial position, results of operations and cash flows for the Successor period, as defined hereinafter. All comparisons presented are with respect to the prior-year period, unless stated otherwise. The following discussion should be read in conjunction with our audited consolidated financial statements as of September 30, 2023 (Successor) and for the four months ended September 30, 2023 (Successor), the consolidated and combined financial statements as of September 30, 2022 (Predecessor) and for the eight months ended May 31, 2023 (Predecessor) and the year ended September 30, 2022 (Predecessor), as well as the unaudited condensed and consolidated financial statements as of March 31, 2024 and September 30, 2023 (Successor) and for the three and six months ended March 31, 2024 (Successor), and the Unaudited condenses, consolidated, and combined financial statements for the three and six months ended March 31, 2023 (Predecessor). Unless the context indicates otherwise, references in this “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” to the “Company,” “CT,” “Copeland,” “we,” “us” and “our” mean (1) the Climate Technologies Business (or “Climate Technologies”) prior to the consummation of the Transactions and (2) Emerald JV Holdings L.P (“JV NewCo”) and its consolidated subsidiaries thereafter. As a result of the Transactions, a new basis of accounting was created on May 31, 2023. Periods prior to May 31, 2023 reflect the consolidated and combined financial statements of Climate Technologies prior to the Acquisition (referred to herein as the “Predecessor” period). Periods subsequent to May 31,2023, reflect the consolidated financial statements of JV NewCo after the Acquisition (referred to herein as the “Successor” period). JV NewCo’s assets and liabilities were adjusted to fair value on the closing date of the Acquisition. Due to the change in the basis of accounting, each of the (i) consolidated and combined financial statements for the Predecessor and the consolidated financial statements for the Successor and (ii) unaudited condensed, consolidated and combined financial statements for the Predecessor and the unaudited condensed and consolidated financial statements for the Successor are not comparable._

Subsubsection Title: Existing Dollar Notes
Subsubsection Text: On May 19, 2023, we issued $2,275,000,000 aggregate principal amount of 6.625% Senior Secured Notes due 2030 (the “May 2023 Dollar Notes”) under an Indenture dated May 19,2023 (as amended and supplemented, the “Indenture”), and on February 6, 2024, we issued an additional $500,000,000 aggregate principal amount of 6.625% Senior Secured Notes due 2030 (the “February 2024 Dollar Notes”) under the Indenture. The February 2024 Dollar Notes have identical terms and conditions, other than issue date and offering price, as the May 2023 Dollar Notes and vote together as a single class, with the same Common Code and ISIN, and are fungible with, the May 2023 Dollar Notes.

Subsubsection Title: Existing Euro Notes
Subsubsection Text: On May 19, 2023, we issued €455,000,000 aggregate principal amount of 6.375% Senior Secured Notes due 2030 (the “May 2023 Euro Notes”) under the Indenture, and on February 6, 2024, we issued an additional €230,000,000 aggregate principal amount of 6.375% Senior Secured Notes due 2030 (the “February 2024 Euro Notes”) under the Indenture. The February 2024 Euro Notes have identical terms and conditions, other than issue date and offering price, as the May 2023 Euro Notes and vote together as a single class, with the same Common Code and ISIN, and are fungible with, the May 2023 Euro Notes.

Subsubsection Title: Optional Redemption
Subsubsection Text: We may, at our option, redeem at any time and from time to time prior to June 15, 2026 some or all of each series of the Existing Notes, in whole or in part, at 100% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding, the date of redemption plus the applicable “make-whole premium.” Additionally, prior to June 15, 2026, we may, at our option, redeem at any time and from time, up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of each series of the Existing Notes with an amount not to exceed the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price of (i) 106.625% of the aggregate principal amount, in the case of the Existing Dollar Notes, or (ii) 106.375% of the aggregate principal amount, in the case of the Existing Euro Notes, to be redeemed, plus any accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding, the date of redemption. Furthermore, at any time prior to June 15, 2026, we may, at our option, redeem at any time and from time to time, up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of each series of the Existing Notes during each calendar year following the applicable issuance date of the Existing Notes at a redemption price of 103.000% of the aggregate principal amount of each series of the Existing Notes to be redeemed, plus any accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding, the date of redemption. From and after June 15, 2026, we may, at our option, redeem at any time and from time to time, each series of the Existing Notes, in whole or in part, at the applicable redemption prices, plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding, the date of redemption. The Existing Notes will mature on June 15, 2030.

Subsubsection Title: Guarantees
Subsubsection Text: All of our obligations under the Existing Notes are fully and unconditionally guaranteed, jointly and severally, by Holdings and each of our wholly-owned domestic restricted subsidiaries that guarantee our Senior Secured Credit Facility. -----

Subsubsection Title: Collateral
Subsubsection Text: The Existing Notes and the guarantees thereof are secured on an equal priority basis with our Term Loan Facilities by the assets that secure our Term Loan Facilities, which consist of a senior-priority lien on the Fixed Asset Priority Collateral, and a junior-priority lien on the ABL Priority Collateral, in each case, subject to certain limitations and exceptions and permitted liens.

Subsubsection Title: Covenants
Subsubsection Text: The indenture governing the Existing Notes contains a number of covenants that, among other things, restrict, subject to certain exceptions, our and our restricted subsidiaries’ ability to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness or issue disqualified stock or certain preferred stock; - pay dividends and make other distributions or repurchase stock; - make certain investments; - create or incur certain liens; - transfer or sell certain assets; - enter into restrictions affecting the ability of certain restricted subsidiaries to make distributions, loans or advances or transfer assets to us or the guarantors; - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; - designate restricted subsidiaries as unrestricted subsidiaries; and - merge, consolidate or transfer or sell all or substantially all of our and the guarantors’ assets. The Indenture contains change of control provisions and certain customary affirmative covenants and events of default. Subject to certain exceptions, the Indenture permits us and our restricted subsidiaries to incur additional indebtedness, including secured indebtedness.

Subsubsection Title: Interest rate and fees
Subsubsection Text: Borrowings under the Term Loan B Facility bear interest, at the Borrower’s option, at a rate per annum equal to an applicable margin over either (a) a base rate determined by reference to the highest of (1) the “Prime Rate” in the United States as published in The Wall Street Journal, (2) the federal funds effective rate plus 1/2 of 1% and (3) Term SOFR for a one month interest period plus 1.00% or (b) a Term SOFR rate determined by reference to the applicable Term SOFR rate published on the Federal Reserve Bank of New York’s Website for the interest period relevant to such borrowing, subject to a Term SOFR floor of 0.00%. Borrowings under the Term Loan A Facility bear interest, at the Borrower’s option, at a rate per annum equal to an applicable margin over either (a) a base rate determined by reference to the highest of (1) the “Prime Rate” in the United States as published in The Wall Street Journal, (2) the federal funds effective rate plus 1/2 of 1% and (3) Term SOFR for a one month interest period plus 1.00% or (b) a Term SOFR rate determined by reference to the applicable Term SOFR rate published on the Federal Reserve Bank of New York’s Website for the interest period relevant to such borrowing, subject to a Term SOFR floor of 0.00%.

Subsubsection Title: Prepayments
Subsubsection Text: The Term Loan B Facility contains customary mandatory prepayment requirements, including with respect to excess cash flow, asset sale proceeds and proceeds from certain incurrences of indebtedness. The Term Loan A Facility contains customary mandatory prepayment requirements, including with respect to asset sale proceeds and proceeds from certain incurrences of indebtedness, but do not contain a mandatory prepayment requirement with respect to excess cash flow. We may voluntarily repay outstanding loans under either Term Loan Facility at any time without premium or penalty.

Subsubsection Title: Amortization and maturity
Subsubsection Text: Commencing with the second full fiscal quarter following the closing of the Term Loan B Facility, the term loans under the Term Loan B Facility amortize in equal quarterly installments in an aggregate annual amount equal to 1.00% of the original principal amount of such term loans, with the balance being payable on the date that is seven years after the closing of the Term Loan B Facility. The term loans under the Term Loan A Facility amortize in quarterly installments, which amortization commenced with the first full fiscal quarter following the closing of the Term Loan A Facility, in a quarterly amount equal to (i) from the first full fiscal quarter following the Closing through the eighth full fiscal quarter following the closing of the Term Loan A Facility, 0%, (ii) from the ninth full fiscal quarter following the closing of the Term Loan A Facility through the sixteenth full fiscal quarter following the closing of the Term Loan A Facility, 0.625%, and (iii) from the seventeenth full fiscal quarter following the closing of the Term Loan A Facility until the maturity date of the Term Loan A Facility, 1.875%, in each case of the original principal amount of the Term Loan A Facility and with the balance being payable on the date that is five years after the closing of the Term Loan A Facility.

Subsubsection Title: Guarantee and security
Subsubsection Text: All of our obligations under the Term Loan Facilities and certain hedge agreements and cash management arrangements provided by any lender party to the Term Loan Facilities or any of its affiliates and certain other ----- persons are unconditionally guaranteed by Holdings, the Borrower (with respect to hedge agreements and cash management arrangements not entered into by the Borrower) and each of our existing and subsequently acquired or organized direct or indirect material wholly-owned domestic restricted subsidiaries, with customary exceptions including, among other things, where providing such guarantees is not permitted by law, regulation or contract or would result in material adverse tax consequences. All obligations under the Term Loan Facilities and certain hedge agreements and cash management arrangements provided by any lender party to any Term Loan Facilities or any of its affiliates and certain other persons, and the guarantees of such obligations, are secured, subject to permitted liens and other exceptions, by: (i) a perfected first-priority pledge of all the equity interests of the Borrower and each wholly-owned material restricted subsidiary of the Borrower that is directly held by the Borrower or a subsidiary guarantor (limited, with respect to equity interests, to 65% of the voting power issued by first-tier foreign subsidiaries, CFCs or FSHCOs, as defined under the Credit Agreement except that in certain instances, until the completion of certain post-closing entity restructurings, all of the equity interests issued by a first-tier foreign subsidiary will be pledged), (ii) a perfected first-priority security interests in substantially all tangible and intangible personal property of the Borrower and the subsidiary guarantors (other than ABL Priority Collateral, in respect of which such obligations will be secured by a perfected second-priority security interest).

Subsubsection Title: Certain covenants and events of default
