(15.2) (22.8) Total long-term debt, net .................................................................................... $ 7,579.0 7,498.2 (1) The Euro Notes borrowings are denominated in Euros (EUR) of which the principal amount is €455.0 at 9/30/23 and €685.0 at 3/31/24. _Term Loan Credit Agreement_ On May 31, 2023, Merger Sub, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Company, entered into a credit agreement (the “Term Loan Credit Agreement”). Upon consummation of the Acquisition on the Closing Date, Merger Sub merged with and into EMRLD Borrower, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Company, with EMRLD Borrower surviving such merger. The Term Loan Credit Agreement permitted the Borrower to borrow $450.0 and $2,275.0 under new senior secured term loan facilities, the “Term Loan A Facility” and “Original Term Loan B Facility” respectively and together, the “Original Term Loan Facilities”. On February 6, 2024, EMRLD Borrower entered into an amendment to the Term Loan Credit Agreement, which provided for the incurrence of a new senior secured term “B” loan (the “New Term Loan B Facility”) in an aggregate principal amount of $1,519.3, the proceeds of which, together with the proceeds of the New Notes (defined below) and cash on hand were used to refinance all of the Original Term Loan B ----- Facility and to pay fees, costs and expenses related to the offering of the New Notes and the New Term Loan B Facility (the “Refinancing”). The Term Loan A Facility matures on May 31, 2028 (the “Term Loan A Maturity Date”), and amortizes in quarterly installments in an amount equal to, (i) commencing with the last business day of the fiscal quarter ending September 30, 2025 and through and including the last business day of the fiscal quarter ending June 30, 2027, 0.625% of the original principal amount of the Term Loan A Facility and (ii) thereafter and through and including the Term Loan A Maturity Date, of 1.875% of the original principal amount of the Term Loan A Facility, with the remaining principal balance due in a lump sum on the Term Loan A Maturity Date. Borrowings under the Term Loan A Facility bear interest at an adjusted Term Secured Overnight Financing Rate (“Term SOFR Rate”) plus a margin of between 2.25% and 2.75% per annum (based on EMRLD Borrower’s first lien net leverage ratio), subject to a Term SOFR Rate floor of 0.00%. The New Term Loan B Facility matures on May 31, 2030 (the “Term Loan B Maturity Date”), and commencing with the fiscal quarter ending March 31, 2024, amortizes in equal quarterly installments of 0.25% of the original principal amount of the New Term Loan B Facility, with the remaining principal balance due in a lump sum on the Term Loan B Maturity Date. Borrowings under the Original Term Loan B Facility bore interest at Term SOFR Rate plus a margin of between 2.75% and 3.0% per annum (based on EMRLD Borrower’s first lien net leverage ratio), subject to a Term SOFR Rate floor of 0.00%. Borrowings under the New Term Loan B Facility bear interest at the Term SOFR Rate plus a margin of between 2.25% and 2.50% per annum (based on EMRLD Borrower’s first lien net leverage ratio), subject to a Term SOFR Rate floor of 0.00%. Any voluntary prepayment, refinancing or repricing of the term loans under the New Term Loan B Facility in connection with certain repricing transactions that occur prior to the six-month anniversary of the closing of the New Term Loan B Facility are subject to a prepayment premium of 1.00% of the principal amount of such term loans so prepaid, refinanced or repriced, subject to certain exceptions. In connection with the Original Term Loan Facilities, the Company incurred and paid debt issuance costs of $100.3, which was capitalized and was amortized through interest expense over the term of the Original Term Loan Facilities. The incurrence of the New Term Loan B Facility coincided with the full extinguishment of the Original Term Loan B Facility. The Company recognized a loss on debt extinguishment related to the unamortized issuance costs and discount totaling $96.8 for the period ended March 31, 2024. The New Term Loan B Facility was issued at an Original Issuance Discount (“OID”) of $1.9. In connection with issuing the New Term Loan B Facility, the Company incurred and paid debt issuance costs of $1.7 and $1.2, respectively, which was capitalized and is amortized through interest expense over the respective remaining term of the New Term Loan B Facility. As of March 31, 2024, $17.9 of debt issuance costs are capitalized for the Term Loan Facilities. The interest rate in effect for the Term Loan Facilities as of March 31, 2024, was 8.063% and 7.790% for the Term Loan A Facility and the New Term Loan B Facility, respectively. _Dollar and Euro Notes_ On May 19, 2023, Merger Sub and Emerald Co-Issuer Inc (“Emerald Co-Issuer”), a direct subsidiary of Merger Sub, issued senior secured notes in the aggregate principal amount of $2,275 and aggregate principal amount of €455 (or $500.0 U.S. dollar equivalent, based on the exchange rate of approximately $1.10 per €1.00) (collectively, the “Original Notes”). The Original Dollar Notes mature on December 15, 2030, and bear interest at a rate of 6.625% per annum starting on May 19, 2023. The Original Euro Notes mature on December 15, 2030, and bear interest at a rate of 6.375% per annum starting on May 19, 2023. The effective interest rates for the Original Dollar Notes and Original Euro Notes as of March 31, 2024, were 6.855% and 6.567%, respectively. In connection with the New Term Loan B Facility, on February 6, 2024, EMRLD Borrower, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Company, and Emerald Co-Issuer, a direct subsidiary of EMRLD Borrower, issued new senior secured notes in the aggregate principal amount of $750.0, including $500.0 of Dollar Notes (“New Dollar Notes”) and €230.0 (or $250.0 U.S. dollar equivalent, based on the exchange rate of approximately $1.09 per €1.00) of Euro Notes (“New Euro Notes), collectively, the “New Notes”. The New Notes were issued as additional notes under the indenture governing the Original Notes. The New Dollar Notes were issued at a premium of 100.750, resulting in a premium of $3.8. The New Euro Notes were issued at a premium of 104.250, resulting in a USD premium of approximately $10.6. The New Notes have the same terms as the Original Notes. The effective interest rates for the ----- New Dollar Notes and the New Euro Notes as of March 31, 2024, were 6.7413% and 5.9923%, respectively. Principal on both the Original Notes and New Notes will be payable upon maturity. In connection with the Original Notes and the New Notes, the Company incurred and paid debt issuance costs of $47.8, which was capitalized and is amortized through interest expense over the respective remaining term of the Original Notes and New Notes. As of March 31, 2024, $44.9 of debt issuance costs are still capitalized for both the Original Notes and New Notes. _ABL Credit Agreement_ On May 31, 2023, the Merger Sub entered into a credit agreement (the “ABL Credit Agreement”). Upon consummation of the Acquisition on the Closing Date, Merger Sub merged with and into EMRLD Borrower with EMRLD Borrower surviving such merger. The ABL Credit Agreement provides the Company with access to an up to $700.0 senior secured asset-based revolving credit facility (the “Revolving Credit Facility” and, together with the Term Loan Facilities, the “Senior Secured Credit Facilities”). In connection with the Revolving Credit Facility, the Company incurred and paid debt issuance costs of $22.3, which was capitalized in other assets and is amortized through interest expense over the remaining term of the Revolving Credit Facility. As of December 31, 2023, $19.0 of debt issuance costs are still capitalized. Borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility bear interest at Term SOFR Rate plus a margin of between 1.5% and 2.0% per annum (based on the Borrower’s average excess availability), subject to a Term SOFR Rate floor of 0.00%. The Revolving Credit Facility also requires a commitment fee of between 0.25% and 0.375% per annum (based on average daily revolving credit exposure) on undrawn commitments to be paid quarterly in arrears. The Revolving Credit Facility terminates on May 31, 2028. As of March 31, 2024, the Company had total capacity and available capacity of $408.6 and $399.5, respectively, under the Revolving Credit Facility. The debt agreements governing the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Original and New Notes described above contain covenants requiring compliance with, and govern among other things, restrictions on additional borrowings, investments (including acquisitions) and distributions. As of March 31, 2024, and at all times during the period, the Company was in compliance with its debt covenants. _Emerson Notes_ On May 31, 2023, the Emerson Notes Issuer, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company, issued two unsecured notes (the Emerson Notes), to EMR Holdings, Inc., an affiliate of Emerson, in the aggregate amount of $2,250.0. The Emerson Notes will mature on May 31, 2033. No debt issuance costs were incurred associated with the issuance of the Emerson Notes. The Emerson Notes include provisions for the payment of interest on the outstanding principal amount by adding the interest to the unpaid principal amount, which is referred to as paid in kind (“PIK”) interest. Interest compounds on a semi-annual basis. The stated interest rate of the Emerson Notes is 5% per annum and the effective rate as of March 31, 2024, is 5.944%. Upon a change of control, the Company is required to prepay the entire principal amount, plus accrued unpaid interest through the prepayment date without any premium or penalty. The Emerson Notes are structurally subordinated to the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Original and New Notes. Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Acquisition, the Company created two new incentive plans for its employees’ performance and retention purposes, the Emerald JV Holdings L.P. 2023 Unit Incentive Plan (“MIP”) and the Long-Term Incentive Plan (“LTIP”). During the three and six months ended March 31, 2024, the Company recognized $1.4 and $3.5, respectively, in sharebased compensation expense, which was reported in selling, general and administrative expenses (“SG&A”) in the condensed consolidated statement of operations. All of this expense related to the Time-Vesting Options (described further below). There were certain Time-Vesting and Performance-Vesting Options (described further below) granted and forfeited during the three and six months ended March 31, 2024, described below. _Long-Term Incentive Plan_ Under the terms of the LTIP, employees are granted awards (the “LTIP Awards”) that become payable upon meeting both a service condition (the “LTIP Service Condition”) and a liquidity event condition (the “LTIP Liquidity Condition”). Awards issued under the LTIP have a maximum contractual term of the earlier to occur of the date on which the vested award amount has been settled or 7 years. LTIP Awards are liability classified since they allow for settlement in cash at the option of the Company. As of March 31, 2024, the unvested and outstanding Long-Term Incentive Plan Awards had an aggregate value of $16.1 of unrecognized share-based compensation expense. _Unit Incentive Plan_ The MIP allows for the issuance of up to 466,881,550 units. Under the terms of the MIP, employees are awarded stock options (“Options”) or Unit Appreciation Right awards (“UARs”). Awards issued under the MIP have a maximum ----- contractual term of 10 years. Options under the MIP are equity classified. UARs are liability classified since they require settlement in cash. Under the MIP, one half of the Options and UARs will vest in five (5) equal installments on the first through fifth anniversaries of the vesting commencement date, so long as the employee remains employed by the Company through the applicable vesting date (“Time-Vesting Units”). One half of the Options and UARs granted under the MIP may vest upon a liquidity event based on the extent that Blackstone Capital Partners VIII L.P. and its Affiliates (“Sponsor”) receives cash proceeds in respect of the Sponsor’s original investment in an amount that meets certain multiples on invested capital and internal rate of return hurdles subject to the recipient’s continued employment at the time the hurdles are met (“Performance-Vesting Units”). Additionally, with regard to the UARs, both the Time-Vesting Units and Performance-Vesting Units may only be exercised by an employee following a liquidity event. _Options_ Compensation expense for the Time-Vesting Units is recognized on a straight-line basis over the five-year requisite service period. Performance-Vesting Units vest upon the achievement of certain liquidity events which are not considered probable until consummated and, as such, no compensation expense has been recognized.

Subsubsection Text: Certain employees of the Company participate in Emerson’s share-based compensation plans, which include performance shares and restricted stock units. Compensation expense is recognized based on the grant date fair value – or in the case of liability classified awards, the fair value at each reporting date – of the awards, as determined by Emerson under ASC 718, Compensation – Stock Compensation. Share-based compensation expense for the Emerson share-based compensation plans was $2.2 and $11.3 for the three and six months ended March 31, 2023, respectively, and is reflected within SG&A within the condensed, consolidated and combined Statement of Operations. ----- The net parent investment balance included in the condensed, consolidated and combined balance sheets represents Emerson’s historical investment in the Climate Technologies, the Climate Technologies’ accumulated net earnings after income taxes, and the net effect of transactions with Emerson. ----- As a business of Emerson, Climate Technologies had charged for costs directly attributable to Climate Technologies and allocated a portion of Emerson’s general corporate costs. All these costs are reflected in the Climate Technologies’ unaudited condensed and consolidated financial statements in the Predecessor period. Management believes the methodologies and assumptions used to allocate costs to the Climate Technologies are reasonable. Emerson maintains a centralized information technology function that supports its business units. Services provided include application hosting, network support, network security, messaging and technology related services. Charges to Climate Technologies for these services were based on Emerson’s cost and the Climate Technologies’ actual usage. Emerson administers a medical insurance program for its U.S. employees in which Climate Technologies participates and for which it records the cost of claims incurred each period. Climate Technologies participated in other Emerson programs including, but not limited to, workers’ compensation and general and product liability insurance. Other Emerson programs are charged to Climate Technologies based on costs incurred and usage. Climate Technologies utilized Emerson global shared service centers that host Company-dedicated resources providing customer facing support, engineering and back office financial services. Costs for these resources are charged directly to Climate ----- Technologies, with the majority relating to employee compensation and benefits and the remaining portion relating to facility overhead. In addition, general corporate costs incurred by Emerson and trademark and tradename royalties and supply chain services are allocated to Climate Technologies primarily based on its proportionate share of Emerson’s total consolidated revenue and include the cost of support functions such as procurement, logistics, marketing, human resources, legal, finance, internal audit and other Emerson corporate functions. Subsubsection Text: The unaudited condensed and consolidated statements of equity reflect the issuance of general partner’s interest and limited partners’ interest in connection of the Acquisition as detailed in Note 2. As of March 31, 2024, the Company has three main classes of units, General Partner Units, issued to the general partner (“General Partner”), and Class P Units and Common Units, issued to the limited partners (“Limited Partners”). _General Partner Units_ The General Partner has the exclusive power and authority to manage and control the business and operations of the Company. The General Partner is authorized to create additional classes of equity units and can issue an unlimited number of units of any class. As of March 31, 2024, the Company has a singular issued and outstanding unit of General Partner Units. _Limited Partners’ Preferred Equity (Class P Units)_ Class P Units do not contain voting rights (subject to certain standard exceptions) but have priority with respect to rights on the distribution of assets and dividend upon any voluntary or involuntary liquidation and dissolution. Class P Units accrete at an amount equal to 7% per annum. The holder of each Class P Unit has the option to, if permitted by the Class P majority holder, convert the units into Class A-1 Units to participate in tag-along rights of the General Partner LLC Agreement. In the occurrence of an initial public offering, if the price per share of common stock is greater than the Conversion Price, all outstanding Class P Units will automatically convert into an aggregate number of Class A-1 Units, determined by dividing the accreted amount of Class P Units by the Conversion Price (“Mandatory IPO Conversion”). If an initial public offering occurs but does not meet the conditions for Mandatory IPO Conversion, the class P majority holder can elect to have all of the Class P Units converted to Class A-1 Units in the same manner as if a Mandatory IPO Conversion occurs, or, alternatively, can elect to convert the Class P Units into a preferred security that pays interest at a 9% annual rate in cash, on the terms and conditions set forth in the Company’s limited partnership agreement. Upon a change in control or when the holder of Class P Unit elects to participate in tag-along rights, the Class P Units will automatically convert into Class A-1 Units in the amount equal to the greater of the accreted amount of Class P Units divided by the price per Class A-1 Unit or Conversion Price. The Company has 2.0 million Class P Units issued and outstanding as of March 31, 2024. _Conversion Price_ The “Conversion Price” for the Class P Units will be calculated as the product of 1.10 and the common equity consideration in connection with the Acquisition divided by the number of Class A-1 Units acquired by BCP Ruby Limited Partners. The initial and current Conversion Price for the Class P Units is $1.1 per share. The Conversion Price is subject to adjustment upon the occurrence of certain anti-dilutive common stock events, including stock splits, the issuance of common stock dividends. _Limited Partners’ Common Equity (Common Units)_ Common Units consist of Class A-1 Units and Class A-2 Units. The Class A-2 Units are issued to management and do not contain voting rights. Common Units rank subsequent to holders of Class P units in any distributions or dividends. During the six months ended March 31, 2024, 1.0 million Class A-2 units were issued to management for $1.0. As of March 31, 2024, the Company has approximately 4,201.9 million Class A-1 units and 3.0 million Class A-2 units issued and outstanding.

In December 2022, Climate Technologies loaned a subsidiary of Emerson $947.3, and borrowed $947.3 from another Emerson subsidiary. **(17) CONTINGENT LIABILITIES AND COMMITMENTS** The Company is a party to a number of pending legal proceedings and claims, including those involving general and product liability (including asbestos), and other matters. The Company accrues for such liabilities when it is probable that future costs will be incurred and such costs can be reasonably estimated. Accruals are based on developments to date; management’s estimates of the outcomes of these matters; the Company’s experience in contesting, litigating and settling similar matters; and any related insurance coverage. While the Company believes a material adverse impact is unlikely, it is not possible to predict the ultimate outcome of these matters. Given the inherent uncertainty of litigation, a remote possibility exists that a future development could have a material adverse impact on the Company. The Company engages an outside expert to develop an actuarial estimate of its expected costs to resolve all pending and future asbestos claims, including defense costs, as well as its related insurance receivable. The reserve for asbestos litigation, which is recorded on an undiscounted basis, was $53.8 and the insurance receivable was $26.3 as of both March 31, 2024 (Successor) and September 30, 2023 (Successor). As part of the Transaction Agreement, Emerson has indemnified the Company for asbestos liabilities up to $75.0; with Emerson having the right to offset any such amount against the Emerson Notes. The Company anticipates the total amount of claims filed during the 7-year period will be $28.5 with a related insurance receivable of $10.0, and therefore an indemnification receivable equal to $18.5 has been recorded as of both September 30, 2023 and March 31, 2024. The Company is also responsible for environmental remediation at various facilities presently or formerly operated by the Company. The environmental remediation liability is recorded based upon the best estimate of costs to be incurred in light of the progress made in determining the magnitude of remediation costs, the timing, and extent of remedial actions required by governmental authorities. The actual costs the Company will incur are dependent on final determination of contamination and required remedial action, negotiations with governmental authorities with respect to cleanup levels, changes in regulatory requirements, innovations in investigatory and remedial technologies, effectiveness of remedial technologies employed, the ability of other responsible parties to pay, and any insurance or other third-party recoveries. As of March 31, 2024 (Successor) the Company has recorded, on an undiscounted basis, a total liability of $15.9 for environmental remediation-and related legal costs regarding these facilities. Approximately $3.3 and $12.6 was recorded in accrued expenses and other long-term liabilities, respectively. As of September 30, 2023 (Successor), the Company has recorded, on an undiscounted basis, a total liability of $16.6 for ----- environmental remediation-and related legal costs regarding these facilities. Approximately $3.7 and $12.9 was recorded in accrued expenses and other long-term liabilities, respectively. As of March 31, 2024 (Successor), there were no other known contingent liabilities (including guarantees and other claims) that management believes will be material in relation to the Company’s financial statements, nor were there any material commitments outside the normal course of business. **(18) ACCUMULATED OTHER COMPREHENSIVE INCOME (LOSS)** Three Months Ended March 31, Six Months Ended March 31,

Subsubsection Text: Under the terms of the indenture that will govern the notes, we will agree that for so long as any of the notes remain outstanding, we will furnish to the trustee and holders of the notes the information specified therein. See “Description of Notes—Certain Covenants—Reports and Other Information.” We have not, and the initial purchasers have not, authorized anyone to provide you with information other than that provided in this offering memorandum. We take no responsibility for, and can provide no assurance as to the reliability of, any other information that others may give you. You should not assume that the information in this offering memorandum is accurate as of any date other than the date of this offering memorandum. This offering memorandum contains summaries of certain agreements that we have entered into or will enter into in connection with the Transactions and the Seller Notes Repurchase, as applicable, such as the indenture that will govern the notes, the credit agreements that govern the Senior Secured Credit Facilities, the Escrow Agreement, if applicable, and the other agreements described under “Summary—The Transactions,” “Description of Certain Other Indebtedness” and “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions.” The descriptions contained in this offering memorandum of these agreements do not purport to be complete and are subject to, or qualified in their entirety by reference to, the definitive agreements. Copies of the indenture that will govern the notes will be made available without charge to you in response to a written request to us. -----
